      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
      &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
      &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
      &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,

      &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,

  data-animation="none"

  <div class="section-background">

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 41: Overcoming Helplessness</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Feb 22" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Feb 22</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-60339519c0b3b22cdbba60c8"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-c463c8066318b36987aa"><div class="sqs-block-content"><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Introduction</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A concept that I find extremely useful for understanding my life and failure modes is the notion of <strong>helplessness</strong>. Helplessness is when I have a problem in my life that I don’t even <em>try </em>to solve. The problem feels big and overwhelming, and I have no idea where to start. It feels like a background fact of my existence, rather than something that I have agency in and can make progress on.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is an important concept, because it often surrounds the biggest problems in my life - problems of motivation, life goals, career plans, health, romance, fulfilment, etc. I am aware there are problems, I maybe vaguely intend to do something one day, but I don’t actually <em>do </em>anything about it. And this is <strong>insane</strong>! I am much more able to fix a small, inconsequential problem in my life than I am to fix the largest, and most consequential. Larger problems are, naturally, harder to solve. But the times when I have managed to overcome helplessness, I’ve always been able to make <em>some </em>progress - helplessness causes me to massively misallocate effort for improving my life. This is a key example of<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk"> upside risk</a> - the returns of making progress on my biggest problems is <em>massive</em>, and is almost always worth a shot.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Helplessness is a particularly insidious problem because it often passes unnoticed. When I am helpless about a problem it doesn’t feel like I am carefully evaluating the possible options, probability of success, and expected value of pursuing an option. Rather, the idea of solving the problem feels <em>unthinkable</em>. I flinch away from the idea before I can even begin to evaluate the pros and cons, and have a systematic blind spot around working through my helplessness.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Accordingly, I find it valuable to reframe the issue away from <strong>solving </strong>the problem to <strong>making progress </strong>on the problem. If a problem is large enough, making incremental progress is still extremely useful to me. And this makes it feel far less overwhelming - redefining the problem so that the idea of doing anything is <em>thinkable </em>is the first step towards a solution, and it is far easier to imagine making progress than solving a major problem outright. Often, one of the sources of helplessness is a fear of trying to solve the problem and failing - reframing it to be about making progress makes failure a much less visceral possibility</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To be clear, I think that sometimes helplessness <em>is </em>justified. Our largest problems sometimes are overwhelming and intractable. Sometimes the best choice is to just avoid the pain of thinking about them. The core claim I am arguing is that it is very hard to distinguish between justified helplessness, and giving up too early. And that the ability to tell the difference is <em>immensely </em>valuable, and worth far more than the cost of sometimes working on intractably hard problems.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In this article, I will argue for two key techniques for making progress on helplessness:</p><ol data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Actually make time</strong> - when I notice myself feel helpless on a problem, and do not feel like I have ever really tried to solve it, block out a few hours to actually think about it and try to make progress. If I haven’t tried for at least an afternoon to solve a major problem, I have no way of knowing how hard it <em>actually </em>is</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Gain surface area</strong> - Rather than focusing on <em>solving </em>a problem, focus on <em>understanding </em>the problem.</p></li></ol><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Noticing Helplessness</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The first step to overcoming helplessness is<a href="https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/GLPaZamxqkx7XJbXv/the-skill-of-noticing-emotions"> <em>noticing</em></a><em> </em>when I feel helpless, promoting this to conscious attention, and deciding to something about it. This is significantly harder than it sounds, because it is rarely obvious from the inside that I am being irrational - rather, it feels like I am stuck, like the problem is hard and overwhelming. I flinch away from the idea of solving it. The idea of actually doing anything about it is unthinkable.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To notice the major background problems in my life, I find the concept of <strong>Hamming Problems</strong> valuable. Richard Hamming was a researcher at Bell Labs who went around asking other researchers “What is the most important problem in your field?” and then “Why aren’t you working on it?” (this made him surprisingly unpopular). This is an extremely important question to ask yourself in research, and surprisingly hard to think to ask yourself - it’s easy to feel helpless when thinking about the biggest problems, and instead focus on the easy and tractable minor problems you come across. Yet, the returns of identifying and focusing on the most important problems tend to be <em>far </em>higher.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Just as this is a valuable mindset in research, this is a valuable for thinking about my life. My Hamming Problems are my biggest bottlenecks, the most important problems in my life. And I rarely have a good answer for why I am not working on them.<a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/14ZKxHmcb6FUm_2mf1EYEgQoiH6r0AXXMbF82hsvOrAI/edit?usp=sharing"> This worksheet</a> is a great way to elicit these. I think most people are helpless about their Hamming problems, or haven’t even explicitly conceived of them as a problem - they just feel like a background fact. So one powerful way to notice helplessness is to introspect on what your Hamming Problems are and then check whether you feel satisfied with how much you are currently working on them.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another way is just to regularly prompt yourself to check for helplessness. Eg adding ‘what is my current Hamming Problem?’ or ‘what am I currently feeling helpless about?’ to a weekly or monthly review. Or having regular debugging calls (with a friend or with a professional coach), that prompt you to actually think about your problems and search for these failure modes.<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/39-reflection"> There are major benefits to making it the default to reflect on your life</a></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It is far easier to notice helplessness in someone else than yourself. I often find it valuable to ask other people advice on what they think I am being helpless about in my life, or to try to give them advice in turn. You can also hack this by other-ising - imagine you were looking at your life as an outside observer. What is this person missing? What are their biggest bottlenecks? How are they failing to make progress?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise</strong>: Set a<a href="https://www.google.com/search?q=5%20minute%20timer"> 5 minute timer</a> and brainstorm ‘what am I currently feeling helpless about?’</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Actually Make Time</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Now you’ve identified a problem you feel helpless about. What can you actually do about it?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My main advice is to <strong>actually make time </strong>to think about it. Concretely, block out an hour in your calendar to think about the problem, go somewhere quiet and without distractions, and try to explore the problem and make progress.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think this advice can seem weird at first glance, or like it trivialises the problem. But I think this is an important and powerful insight.<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers"> As I’ve discussed before</a>, it is extremely hard to distinguish between the feeling of ‘this problem is genuinely impossible’ and ‘I cannot solve this problem in &lt; 5 seconds and feel stuck’. Only by making time can you tell the difference. For an <em>embarrassing </em>amount of problems in my life, I have spent less than ten minutes making a genuine attempt to solve them.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Further, even if the probability of making meaningful progress in just a few hours is low, it can often still be extremely worth it. For the biggest problems in my life, I would happily trade hundreds of hours of effort for a robust and lasting solution. I try to have the rule for myself that if I <em>ever </em>have a problem that feels important, and I have not spent at least an hour thinking about it, something has gone wrong. Ultimately, spending a few hours fruitlessly thinking is no great loss, while the potential benefits are <em>massive</em>. And in practice, I’ve had a great success rate with trying this. This is an excellent example of<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk"> upside risk</a>.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Interestingly, despite it feeling clear on a meta level that it’s worth spending large chunks of time working on the problems I feel helpless about, it rarely feels worth it on a gut level. These problems are mostly background things, and rarely feel <em>urgent</em>. My existing commitments and goals always feel far more important, and I feel too busy to make space for this kind of thing. Accordingly, I think a valuable pre-condition to being able to make time is <a href="http://neelnanda.io/blog/38-slack">having Slack </a>in your life - having enough spare capacity that you <em>can </em>afford to make time for this kind of thing without it feeling like a major sacrifice. The mindset to aim for is ‘sure, I can spend two hours thinking about this - it’s no big deal if it doesn’t go anywhere’</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In general, I think it is extremely difficult to judge the value of spending time working on a problem - it is hard to simulate the worth of the ideas you haven’t had yet. So I think people systematically underestimate the value of taking time to think about a problem. If you feel sceptical that this idea would actually help, I urge you to try it! On a meta-level, there’s significant value of information in trying this - if it fails once, you’ve lost an hour. If you find it useful, this is a tool for making progress on overwhelming problems again and again!</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Gain Surface Area</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Hopefully I have now convinced you to make time on the problems that you feel overwhelmed and helpless about. But this isn’t concrete. What do you actually <em>do </em>in this time?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Part of the pathology of helplessness for me is a perceived need to <em>solve </em>the problem. It feels like it’s only worth working on a problem if I can solve it, it’s a hard problem so I obviously won’t be able to solve it, so I just give up and don’t even bother. My main solution to this is to redefine the problem, my goal is to <strong>make incremental progress</strong>, not to <em>solve </em>it.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The next step is to orient towards what I call <strong>gaining surface area</strong>. The surface area I have on a problem is the knowledge I have about it: how well I understand it, the links between it and other problems, the solutions that I know <em>don’t </em>work, the way it connects to the underlying way my mind works, etc. And the main way I think of making progress on a problem is trying to gain surface area. This approach breaks the loop of ‘fear of failure -&gt; doing nothing’, because it’s <em>easy </em>to gain surface area. If I think about the problem and explore it, I’ve gained surface area. If I try an experimental solution and it fails, by examining why it fails I have gained surface area. To solve a problem, it feels like I need to find the right place to start, but to gain surface area I can start anywhere. I find this concept particularly useful when trying to solve personal problems, but also useful for thinking about ideas and confusions in general, eg when trying to get unstuck during research.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The mindset of gaining surface area is very different from the mindset of trying to solve a problem - it feels far more exploratory and curiosity driven, in free association mode, seeing what connections arise. While to me, deciding to solve a problem feels much more focused, yet laden with obligation and anxiety to be getting somewhere and to be making progress fast enough.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Gaining surface area is much easier than solving the problem outright, but it is <em>also </em>extremely useful for actually solving it. Often a problem feels overwhelming because I just don’t understand it. Once I have enough surface area, it is <em>far </em>easier to generate solutions and see where my thoughts take me. If I don’t understand a problem well enough, I can easily focus my effort on the symptoms while neglecting the root cause. Even if I don’t make any progress, often just understanding where a problem comes from makes it feel more emotionally OK, and easier to deal with.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some approaches for gaining surface area:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Take a blank piece of paper, and just brain-dump whatever comes to mind on to the paper. Have low standards for relevance, and just see what happens</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Try to write out a complete model of the problem from scratch. Notice the parts that feel like holes or confusions</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Generate hypothetical scenarios where the problem might arise. Mentally simulate these and see whether the problem arises. Introspect on how you feel, and try to notice subtle details</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Or think through past examples and introspect on how you felt</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Suppose it’s a month from now and you solved this problem - it no longer feels like an issue. What happened?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask friends for advice, see if they relate to your problem, and which examples feel relevant to them</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask them for the ‘<a href="http://mindingourway.com/obvious-advice/">obvious advice</a>’ - what’s the first thing they’d try to solve the problem?</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers">Be creative</a>. Generate as many ideas relevant to the problem as you can. <a href="http://mindingourway.com/obvious-advice/">Babble </a>- focus on quantity over quality</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Eg solution ideas, past examples, connected problems</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Put yourself in a low pressure environment, eg going for a walk with no distractions, and gently explore the problem. See what associations come to mind</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Experiment with ways to solve aspects of the problem. Make time to reflect on how it went, review, patch and iterate. If it succeeds, awesome! If not, try to understand <em>why </em>it failed - if you understand this, you’ve still learned something!</p></li></ul><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Examples</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This has all been pretty abstract so far, so here are some examples of ways I/my friends have used this. Hopefully at least one resonates with you!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I don’t have clear high-level goals and lack direction</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Spend an hour trying to write out a list of high-level goals, introspecting on which goals feel most exciting. Check in on whether the list feels complete</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I think I might want to take a year out, but the idea feels overwhelming and I’m concerned that I’ll waste it</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Make a list of at least 50 worthwhile things to do with a year out. Just try to get ideas down, rather than having high standards for only<em> </em>“good” ideas</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I buy the idea that AI Safety is really important on an intellectual level, but feel a gut level skepticism</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Spend an hour writing out the arguments for and against, and trying to poke holes in them</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I feel fully invested in my career plan, and find it difficult to entertain the idea that an alternative path might be better</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Assume I cannot do my current path. Spend an hour generating alternate paths and fleshing them out. At the end of the hour, check whether I feel excited about any of them</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I feel anxious and overwhelmed at work, and feel like I am meandering rather than having direction</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Write out my progress so far and possible next steps. Write out my possible high-level goals, and evaluate which ones I care about on a gut-level. Convert this into a concrete plan that I feel excited about</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I lack close friends and companionship, and feel lonely</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Think about how I am currently meeting people and trying to connect with them. Generate at least 10 ideas for meeting new people and forming connections. Pick my favourite, make a concrete plan for doing this, and implement it.</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem: </strong>I feel stuck in a rut at work, kinda bored, and like I’m not learning much</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution: </strong>Introspect on what skills I <em>could </em>learn over the next year, and which ones feel most important. Pick my favourite, and generate ways I could develop this at work, and make a plan to do this</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem: </strong>I feel unfit, and know I should be exercising more, but feel confused and overwhelmed by what to do about this</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution</strong>: List at least 10 ways I could do regular exercise. Pick the one that I feel most excited about, and commit to doing it for the next week. At the end of the week, check in on whether I want to continue, or try the next one on the list</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise: </strong>Pick a problem you feel helpless about. Do you feel satisfied with how much effort you’ve put in? If not, schedule yourself an hour to think about it. Beforehand, write down a prediction for how useful you’ll find the exercise, and compare that to how you feel afterwards</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Conclusion</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Overall, I think that the feeling of helplessness on important problems is extremely common, insidious, hard to notice and a major bottleneck on me and many of my friends. I think that time spent overcoming helplessness is extremely well spent.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The core mindset shift I am arguing for is to notice when a problem is <strong>important</strong>, and to feel excited about any incremental progress you make on important problems. Get to a point where you <em>want </em>to try, rather than flinching away from fear of failure and perfectionism. Even if the problem is hard and overwhelming, orient such that you are satisfied with it being <em>better</em>, rather than frustrated that it is unresolved. Experiment, be in flow, and be willing to try anything and see what sticks. Build the reflex of <strong>actually trying</strong> - when you notice ‘I am complaining about a problem I have put absolutely no effort into’, make some time to do something about it,&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But this reflex is just one way of achieving the mindset, the mindset is the important part. Some alternate ways to make progress on helplessness:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask friends for help and advice</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Seek professional help, eg from a coach or therapist</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Other-ise: <em>imagine </em>you are instead giving advice to a friend who shares your problems. What are the obvious things for that friend to do? And are you already doing them?</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And finally, helplessness is often the most important when it is hardest to notice. What are your biggest problems? What do you feel most powerless about? And do you feel satisfied that you’ve put in as much effort as you could have?</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">

64 64"><path d="M0,0v64h64V0H0z M39.6,22l-2.8,0c-2.2,0-2.6,1.1-2.6,2.6V28h5.3l-0.7,5.3h-4.6V47h-5.5V33.3H24V28h4.6V24 c0-4.6,2.8-7,6.9-7c2,0,3.6,0.1,4.1,0.2V22z"/></symbol><symbol id="linkedin-unauth-icon" viewBox="0 0 64 64"><path d="M20.4,44h5.4V26.6h-5.4V44z M23.1,18c-1.7,0-3.1,1.4-3.1,3.1c0,1.7,1.4,3.1,3.1,3.1 c1.7,0,3.1-1.4,3.1-3.1C26.2,19.4,24.8,18,23.1,18z     vertical-alignment--middle

  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
      &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
      &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
      &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,

      &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,

  <div class="section-background">

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 41: Overcoming Helplessness</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Feb 22" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Feb 22</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-60339519c0b3b22cdbba60c8"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-c463c8066318b36987aa"><div class="sqs-block-content"><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Introduction</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A concept that I find extremely useful for understanding my life and failure modes is the notion of <strong>helplessness</strong>. Helplessness is when I have a problem in my life that I don’t even <em>try </em>to solve. The problem feels big and overwhelming, and I have no idea where to start. It feels like a background fact of my existence, rather than something that I have agency in and can make progress on.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is an important concept, because it often surrounds the biggest problems in my life - problems of motivation, life goals, career plans, health, romance, fulfilment, etc. I am aware there are problems, I maybe vaguely intend to do something one day, but I don’t actually <em>do </em>anything about it. And this is <strong>insane</strong>! I am much more able to fix a small, inconsequential problem in my life than I am to fix the largest, and most consequential. Larger problems are, naturally, harder to solve. But the times when I have managed to overcome helplessness, I’ve always been able to make <em>some </em>progress - helplessness causes me to massively misallocate effort for improving my life. This is a key example of<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk"> upside risk</a> - the returns of making progress on my biggest problems is <em>massive</em>, and is almost always worth a shot.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Helplessness is a particularly insidious problem because it often passes unnoticed. When I am helpless about a problem it doesn’t feel like I am carefully evaluating the possible options, probability of success, and expected value of pursuing an option. Rather, the idea of solving the problem feels <em>unthinkable</em>. I flinch away from the idea before I can even begin to evaluate the pros and cons, and have a systematic blind spot around working through my helplessness.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Accordingly, I find it valuable to reframe the issue away from <strong>solving </strong>the problem to <strong>making progress </strong>on the problem. If a problem is large enough, making incremental progress is still extremely useful to me. And this makes it feel far less overwhelming - redefining the problem so that the idea of doing anything is <em>thinkable </em>is the first step towards a solution, and it is far easier to imagine making progress than solving a major problem outright. Often, one of the sources of helplessness is a fear of trying to solve the problem and failing - reframing it to be about making progress makes failure a much less visceral possibility</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To be clear, I think that sometimes helplessness <em>is </em>justified. Our largest problems sometimes are overwhelming and intractable. Sometimes the best choice is to just avoid the pain of thinking about them. The core claim I am arguing is that it is very hard to distinguish between justified helplessness, and giving up too early. And that the ability to tell the difference is <em>immensely </em>valuable, and worth far more than the cost of sometimes working on intractably hard problems.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In this article, I will argue for two key techniques for making progress on helplessness:</p><ol data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Actually make time</strong> - when I notice myself feel helpless on a problem, and do not feel like I have ever really tried to solve it, block out a few hours to actually think about it and try to make progress. If I haven’t tried for at least an afternoon to solve a major problem, I have no way of knowing how hard it <em>actually </em>is</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Gain surface area</strong> - Rather than focusing on <em>solving </em>a problem, focus on <em>understanding </em>the problem.</p></li></ol><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Noticing Helplessness</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The first step to overcoming helplessness is<a href="https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/GLPaZamxqkx7XJbXv/the-skill-of-noticing-emotions"> <em>noticing</em></a><em> </em>when I feel helpless, promoting this to conscious attention, and deciding to something about it. This is significantly harder than it sounds, because it is rarely obvious from the inside that I am being irrational - rather, it feels like I am stuck, like the problem is hard and overwhelming. I flinch away from the idea of solving it. The idea of actually doing anything about it is unthinkable.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To notice the major background problems in my life, I find the concept of <strong>Hamming Problems</strong> valuable. Richard Hamming was a researcher at Bell Labs who went around asking other researchers “What is the most important problem in your field?” and then “Why aren’t you working on it?” (this made him surprisingly unpopular). This is an extremely important question to ask yourself in research, and surprisingly hard to think to ask yourself - it’s easy to feel helpless when thinking about the biggest problems, and instead focus on the easy and tractable minor problems you come across. Yet, the returns of identifying and focusing on the most important problems tend to be <em>far </em>higher.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Just as this is a valuable mindset in research, this is a valuable for thinking about my life. My Hamming Problems are my biggest bottlenecks, the most important problems in my life. And I rarely have a good answer for why I am not working on them.<a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/14ZKxHmcb6FUm_2mf1EYEgQoiH6r0AXXMbF82hsvOrAI/edit?usp=sharing"> This worksheet</a> is a great way to elicit these. I think most people are helpless about their Hamming problems, or haven’t even explicitly conceived of them as a problem - they just feel like a background fact. So one powerful way to notice helplessness is to introspect on what your Hamming Problems are and then check whether you feel satisfied with how much you are currently working on them.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another way is just to regularly prompt yourself to check for helplessness. Eg adding ‘what is my current Hamming Problem?’ or ‘what am I currently feeling helpless about?’ to a weekly or monthly review. Or having regular debugging calls (with a friend or with a professional coach), that prompt you to actually think about your problems and search for these failure modes.<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/39-reflection"> There are major benefits to making it the default to reflect on your life</a></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It is far easier to notice helplessness in someone else than yourself. I often find it valuable to ask other people advice on what they think I am being helpless about in my life, or to try to give them advice in turn. You can also hack this by other-ising - imagine you were looking at your life as an outside observer. What is this person missing? What are their biggest bottlenecks? How are they failing to make progress?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise</strong>: Set a<a href="https://www.google.com/search?q=5%20minute%20timer"> 5 minute timer</a> and brainstorm ‘what am I currently feeling helpless about?’</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Actually Make Time</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Now you’ve identified a problem you feel helpless about. What can you actually do about it?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My main advice is to <strong>actually make time </strong>to think about it. Concretely, block out an hour in your calendar to think about the problem, go somewhere quiet and without distractions, and try to explore the problem and make progress.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think this advice can seem weird at first glance, or like it trivialises the problem. But I think this is an important and powerful insight.<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers"> As I’ve discussed before</a>, it is extremely hard to distinguish between the feeling of ‘this problem is genuinely impossible’ and ‘I cannot solve this problem in &lt; 5 seconds and feel stuck’. Only by making time can you tell the difference. For an <em>embarrassing </em>amount of problems in my life, I have spent less than ten minutes making a genuine attempt to solve them.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Further, even if the probability of making meaningful progress in just a few hours is low, it can often still be extremely worth it. For the biggest problems in my life, I would happily trade hundreds of hours of effort for a robust and lasting solution. I try to have the rule for myself that if I <em>ever </em>have a problem that feels important, and I have not spent at least an hour thinking about it, something has gone wrong. Ultimately, spending a few hours fruitlessly thinking is no great loss, while the potential benefits are <em>massive</em>. And in practice, I’ve had a great success rate with trying this. This is an excellent example of<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk"> upside risk</a>.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Interestingly, despite it feeling clear on a meta level that it’s worth spending large chunks of time working on the problems I feel helpless about, it rarely feels worth it on a gut level. These problems are mostly background things, and rarely feel <em>urgent</em>. My existing commitments and goals always feel far more important, and I feel too busy to make space for this kind of thing. Accordingly, I think a valuable pre-condition to being able to make time is <a href="http://neelnanda.io/blog/38-slack">having Slack </a>in your life - having enough spare capacity that you <em>can </em>afford to make time for this kind of thing without it feeling like a major sacrifice. The mindset to aim for is ‘sure, I can spend two hours thinking about this - it’s no big deal if it doesn’t go anywhere’</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In general, I think it is extremely difficult to judge the value of spending time working on a problem - it is hard to simulate the worth of the ideas you haven’t had yet. So I think people systematically underestimate the value of taking time to think about a problem. If you feel sceptical that this idea would actually help, I urge you to try it! On a meta-level, there’s significant value of information in trying this - if it fails once, you’ve lost an hour. If you find it useful, this is a tool for making progress on overwhelming problems again and again!</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Gain Surface Area</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Hopefully I have now convinced you to make time on the problems that you feel overwhelmed and helpless about. But this isn’t concrete. What do you actually <em>do </em>in this time?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Part of the pathology of helplessness for me is a perceived need to <em>solve </em>the problem. It feels like it’s only worth working on a problem if I can solve it, it’s a hard problem so I obviously won’t be able to solve it, so I just give up and don’t even bother. My main solution to this is to redefine the problem, my goal is to <strong>make incremental progress</strong>, not to <em>solve </em>it.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The next step is to orient towards what I call <strong>gaining surface area</strong>. The surface area I have on a problem is the knowledge I have about it: how well I understand it, the links between it and other problems, the solutions that I know <em>don’t </em>work, the way it connects to the underlying way my mind works, etc. And the main way I think of making progress on a problem is trying to gain surface area. This approach breaks the loop of ‘fear of failure -&gt; doing nothing’, because it’s <em>easy </em>to gain surface area. If I think about the problem and explore it, I’ve gained surface area. If I try an experimental solution and it fails, by examining why it fails I have gained surface area. To solve a problem, it feels like I need to find the right place to start, but to gain surface area I can start anywhere. I find this concept particularly useful when trying to solve personal problems, but also useful for thinking about ideas and confusions in general, eg when trying to get unstuck during research.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The mindset of gaining surface area is very different from the mindset of trying to solve a problem - it feels far more exploratory and curiosity driven, in free association mode, seeing what connections arise. While to me, deciding to solve a problem feels much more focused, yet laden with obligation and anxiety to be getting somewhere and to be making progress fast enough.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Gaining surface area is much easier than solving the problem outright, but it is <em>also </em>extremely useful for actually solving it. Often a problem feels overwhelming because I just don’t understand it. Once I have enough surface area, it is <em>far </em>easier to generate solutions and see where my thoughts take me. If I don’t understand a problem well enough, I can easily focus my effort on the symptoms while neglecting the root cause. Even if I don’t make any progress, often just understanding where a problem comes from makes it feel more emotionally OK, and easier to deal with.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some approaches for gaining surface area:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Take a blank piece of paper, and just brain-dump whatever comes to mind on to the paper. Have low standards for relevance, and just see what happens</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Try to write out a complete model of the problem from scratch. Notice the parts that feel like holes or confusions</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Generate hypothetical scenarios where the problem might arise. Mentally simulate these and see whether the problem arises. Introspect on how you feel, and try to notice subtle details</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Or think through past examples and introspect on how you felt</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Suppose it’s a month from now and you solved this problem - it no longer feels like an issue. What happened?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask friends for advice, see if they relate to your problem, and which examples feel relevant to them</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask them for the ‘<a href="http://mindingourway.com/obvious-advice/">obvious advice</a>’ - what’s the first thing they’d try to solve the problem?</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers">Be creative</a>. Generate as many ideas relevant to the problem as you can. <a href="http://mindingourway.com/obvious-advice/">Babble </a>- focus on quantity over quality</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Eg solution ideas, past examples, connected problems</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Put yourself in a low pressure environment, eg going for a walk with no distractions, and gently explore the problem. See what associations come to mind</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Experiment with ways to solve aspects of the problem. Make time to reflect on how it went, review, patch and iterate. If it succeeds, awesome! If not, try to understand <em>why </em>it failed - if you understand this, you’ve still learned something!</p></li></ul><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Examples</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This has all been pretty abstract so far, so here are some examples of ways I/my friends have used this. Hopefully at least one resonates with you!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I don’t have clear high-level goals and lack direction</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Spend an hour trying to write out a list of high-level goals, introspecting on which goals feel most exciting. Check in on whether the list feels complete</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I think I might want to take a year out, but the idea feels overwhelming and I’m concerned that I’ll waste it</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Make a list of at least 50 worthwhile things to do with a year out. Just try to get ideas down, rather than having high standards for only<em> </em>“good” ideas</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I buy the idea that AI Safety is really important on an intellectual level, but feel a gut level skepticism</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Spend an hour writing out the arguments for and against, and trying to poke holes in them</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I feel fully invested in my career plan, and find it difficult to entertain the idea that an alternative path might be better</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Assume I cannot do my current path. Spend an hour generating alternate paths and fleshing them out. At the end of the hour, check whether I feel excited about any of them</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I feel anxious and overwhelmed at work, and feel like I am meandering rather than having direction</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Write out my progress so far and possible next steps. Write out my possible high-level goals, and evaluate which ones I care about on a gut-level. Convert this into a concrete plan that I feel excited about</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem:</strong> I lack close friends and companionship, and feel lonely</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution:</strong> Think about how I am currently meeting people and trying to connect with them. Generate at least 10 ideas for meeting new people and forming connections. Pick my favourite, make a concrete plan for doing this, and implement it.</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem: </strong>I feel stuck in a rut at work, kinda bored, and like I’m not learning much</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution: </strong>Introspect on what skills I <em>could </em>learn over the next year, and which ones feel most important. Pick my favourite, and generate ways I could develop this at work, and make a plan to do this</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Problem: </strong>I feel unfit, and know I should be exercising more, but feel confused and overwhelmed by what to do about this</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Solution</strong>: List at least 10 ways I could do regular exercise. Pick the one that I feel most excited about, and commit to doing it for the next week. At the end of the week, check in on whether I want to continue, or try the next one on the list</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise: </strong>Pick a problem you feel helpless about. Do you feel satisfied with how much effort you’ve put in? If not, schedule yourself an hour to think about it. Beforehand, write down a prediction for how useful you’ll find the exercise, and compare that to how you feel afterwards</p><h3 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Conclusion</strong></h3><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Overall, I think that the feeling of helplessness on important problems is extremely common, insidious, hard to notice and a major bottleneck on me and many of my friends. I think that time spent overcoming helplessness is extremely well spent.&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The core mindset shift I am arguing for is to notice when a problem is <strong>important</strong>, and to feel excited about any incremental progress you make on important problems. Get to a point where you <em>want </em>to try, rather than flinching away from fear of failure and perfectionism. Even if the problem is hard and overwhelming, orient such that you are satisfied with it being <em>better</em>, rather than frustrated that it is unresolved. Experiment, be in flow, and be willing to try anything and see what sticks. Build the reflex of <strong>actually trying</strong> - when you notice ‘I am complaining about a problem I have put absolutely no effort into’, make some time to do something about it,&nbsp;</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But this reflex is just one way of achieving the mindset, the mindset is the important part. Some alternate ways to make progress on helplessness:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Ask friends for help and advice</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Seek professional help, eg from a coach or therapist</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Other-ise: <em>imagine </em>you are instead giving advice to a friend who shares your problems. What are the obvious things for that friend to do? And are you already doing them?</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And finally, helplessness is often the most important when it is hardest to notice. What are your biggest problems? What do you feel most powerless about? And do you feel satisfied that you’ve put in as much effort as you could have?</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">

64 64"><path d="M0,0v64h64V0H0z M39.6,22l-2.8,0c-2.2,0-2.6,1.1-2.6,2.6V28h5.3l-0.7,5.3h-4.6V47h-5.5V33.3H24V28h4.6V24 c0-4.6,2.8-7,6.9-7c2,0,3.6,0.1,4.1,0.2V22z"/></symbol><symbol id="linkedin-unauth-icon" viewBox="0 0 64 64"><path d="M20.4,44h5.4V26.6h-5.4V44z M23.1,18c-1.7,0-3.1,1.4-3.1,3.1c0,1.7,1.4,3.1,3.1,3.1 c1.7,0,3.1-1.4,3.1-3.1C26.2,19.4,24.8,18,23.1,18z           <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">

  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"

      content-width--wide

    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
    &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
    &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
    &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
    &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
    &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,

  data-animation="none"

  <div class="section-background">

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 39: On Reflection</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Dec 14" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Dec 14</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-5fccc90d978da30c56fb4d92"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-1df7a5b31a78432b8d3c"><div class="sqs-block-content"><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Introduction</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-22-the-8020-rule">The world is full of wasted motion</a>. Many things are far below where they should be, many actions fail to achieve their goals, and this includes many of <em>your </em>actions. And this is not because you’re failing, but because achieving your goals is <em>hard</em>.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is obviously not a problem that can ever be <em>solved</em>. But one thing I find interesting is that often my mistakes are obvious and can be fixed, if only someone points them out! Indeed, often I can notice my mistakes, if someone just prompts me to stop and consider what I’m currently getting wrong. The problem is not some deep, ineffable mystery in the world, but rather just that I am not stopping to ask myself the right questions.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Again, I think this is an understandable mistake. The step of zooming out, being meta, and asking myself the right questions is <em>hard</em>. <strong>It is not the default action</strong>. The problem right in front of me always feels urgent, going meta never feels like the thing I should do <em>right now</em>, so I never do it. But this thought pattern <em>is </em>a mistake. What are the common mistakes you make in your life? What things do <em>you </em>miss, until someone points them out to you? Could you be doing better?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My main tool for this is having <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1ixGVgJXIlCXXgf-y0gb64SwsUq_P1ZF4WYdo-5_C5K0/edit?usp=sharing">a weekly review</a> - a routine where I set out a regular time to reflect on my life, how it’s going, and what I want to change. <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">A routine that makes reflection the <em>default </em>in my life</a>. When people are getting started on debugging their life and ask me for first steps, this is one of my main recommendations - I find it extremely useful, and I think it’s a key basis for noticing your mistakes and actually <em>doing </em>something about them. This post is my case for why this is a worthy habit, and how I think about implementing it.</p><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Asking the right questions</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find there’s a lot of value in just making time to stop and reflect on your life, even if you don’t have a concrete plan - this makes reflection and going meta the default, which is the key first step! But I think it is even more valuable to go in with good questions, to get yourself thinking in the right way. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think the importance of good framing is highly underappreciated - my life is full of blind spots and systematic mistakes, but asking the right questions can often make those blind spots obvious. A common example is the planning fallacy: when I take on a new project, I am <em>always </em>too optimistic. I expect things to be easy, for nothing to go wrong, and think I’ll get it done extremely quickly. But inevitably get bogged down in details and distractions, and fall far short of my goal. But, if I instead ask myself the question “how long did this type of project take before?”, and take an average, I am <em>way </em>more accurate. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A key mental move here is <strong>pre-hindsight</strong>: It’s much easier to <em>explain </em>a past event with hindsight, than it is to predict something in the future, or notice something unexpected - the past is concrete and easy to reason about, the future is abstract and harder. But this is just a state of mind! For example, when I am writing an email, I often realise a mistake or missed detail <em>just </em>after I click send. Absolutely nothing has actually changed, but the email goes from a future thing to a past thing. And often this mental shift can happen deliberately - take something vague and fuzzy that my mind wants to flinch away from, and make it concrete. For example, I find it hard to notice mistakes when I make them, but easy to answer “what was the biggest mistake I made this week?” - the key is to make not answering not an option, and to implicitly <em>assume</em> there was a mistake. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some prompts for questions I find helpful:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What mistakes did I make this week?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I being an idiot about?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I missing?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What was my biggest success this week?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What is my biggest bottleneck?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What is the right lesson to take from this week?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In an ideal version of this week, I would have […]</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I currently procrastinating about?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Whose advice will help me solve my problems?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What is my current biggest priority?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s weighing on my mind?</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Of course, the right questions are going to be specific to you! I like questions that focus on what I’m missing, prioritisation, learning and improvement, tracking progress, asking for help, bottlenecks, etc. The right questions for you will come from <em>your </em>goals, and what you often miss out on. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise: </strong>What are some questions that <em>you </em>would like to answer once a week? Are there any past mistakes, that you needed someone else to point out to you? Big, systematic blind spots? Small things, that slip through the cracks? What questions would it have been useful to ask yourself, over the past month?</p><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Make it the default</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It’s easy to agree that going meta and reflecting is valuable, and far harder to actually <em>do </em>it. The core problem is that reflecting often feels important, but rarely feels like the <em>top </em>priority. It’s easy to be stuck in the short-term, chasing whatever is currently top of my mind, and letting my blind spots forever remain blind spots. And I think it is hard to just spontaneously decide to be meta where appropriate. So the second key insight of this post is that you need to <strong>systematise going meta</strong> - make it the default in your life. I personally find it easiest to do this by having a routine - thus the weekly review - but the important part is to follow whatever systems work best for you. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I outline my general thoughts on systematising things in <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">a previous post</a>, but for this, the key parts are to build a <strong>routine </strong>around it, to <strong>minimise decision points </strong>and to <strong>keep the routine sacrosanct</strong>. Some tips:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Set out a clear time once a week, and put this in your calendar. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Make it a clear and consistent time, so it keeps the routine, and so there’s never a <em>decision</em> about when to do it. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Having it be weekly is just a default suggestion, the key is to be <em>regular</em>. Depending on how much you have worth reviewing, some people prefer daily reviews, monthly reviews, etc</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It can also be valuable to have short daily reviews, longer weekly reviews that zoom out more, even longer monthly reviews that zoom out even more, etc - whatever works best for you!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This tiered approach can be useful to eg think about deeper questions, like <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/prioritisation">questioning your current goals</a> - this would be silly to do every day, but can be highly worth the effort once a month</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Have a clear plan for what to do during that time</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This makes there be a clear default</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it valuable to <a href="https://forms.new">make myself a Google Form</a>, with a list of questions, and boxes to answer them in - this makes the review literally just to fill out this form, always with a clear next action, and a clear order</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">By minimising decision points during the review, this helps stop aversion to <em>doing </em>the review build up - make it as low effort as possible!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Remind yourself of why the review is important, and why you care about it, if you ever feel tempted to cancel</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I personally feel fine with changing the time of the review, but try to ensure it feels important to <em>do </em>the review - I haven’t missed a week in the last year</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is easier when there’s some momentum behind the review - invest effort at the start to get yourself to do it. But once you’ve done it a few times, and found it useful, use this to help motivate yourself to keep to it. I find it useful to keep in mind that skipping a review once isn’t just skipping it once - it’s eroding the habit, and making me more likely to skip all future reviews!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you didn’t find it useful, stop doing it!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Though, if you do skip it, try to avoid <a href="http://mindingourway.com/failing-with-abandon/">failing with abandon</a>! A good routine is flexible, and can take a few missed weeks - you do it because it’s <em>useful</em>, not just to maintain a perfect streak</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Getting started: If you like the idea, but feel uncertain whether it’s <em>actually </em>worth the effort, try thinking of it as an experiment! Do it once a week for the next 3 weeks, and at the end of that check whether it’s useful</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it much easier to convince myself to do bounded experiments - I have an aversion to starting unbounded commitments, but I think this is often reasonable!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Making it stick:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Accountability: Use sticks, find ways to get your future self to keep to it</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Set yourself reminders</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Arrange to send an email with the findings of the review to a friend</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Arrange to <em>do </em>the review with a friend - have a weekly check-in call! Accountability buddys are great</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Set yourself financial penalties, with a site like Beeminder</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It’s also great to have positive ways to make it stick, and feel motivating!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Having a buddy can do this - I personally find social things way more motivating</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I do a gratitude practice in mine - thinking about the people who improved my week, and thanking them - this makes me look forwards to it way more!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">At the end, record the key takeaways of the review - this is a way to remind yourself that it’s useful</p></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Scaffold systems</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another benefit of having a weekly time to check in and review your life, is that this makes debugging anything else in your life easier. If you have any new ideas for weekly habits, blind spots, new things you want to try, it’s <em>much </em>easier to attach them to your weekly review. By having a reliable time when you go meta and reflect, it can make everything else in your life go more smoothly! Some suggestions for good things to peg to it: (I’m trying to throw out a ton of suggestions here - I recommend picking the few that seem most helpful. Don’t try to do all of them!)</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Regular debugging - I ask myself what my biggest bottleneck is, then set a 5 minute timer and try to solve it. Sometimes this works! </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it difficult to carve out time for this kind of debugging in the moment - it’s never the default</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Tracking long-term things</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Your mood</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s weighing on your mind</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Long-term goals, eg overcoming anxiety, meeting more people, going outside of your comfort zone</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Productivity - eg, <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/sad">do you feel less productive in winter</a>?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/38-slack">Did I have enough Slack this week</a>?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Was I <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/become-a-person-who-actually-does-things">a person who actually does things?</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">Reviewing and patching systems</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Tracking health and exercise</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/25-friendship">Am I being a good friend</a>? Is there anything I could be doing better?</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Time tracking - what did you spend your time on this week? Was that a good allocation? How do you want to allocate your time next week?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Prioritisation - What are your current goals? Is what you’re working on <em>actually </em>your highest priority?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Motivation - <em>Why </em>are you working on what you’re currently doing? What was a success this week? How did I make progress on my goals?</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This can be really useful when <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/35-standards">my standards are too high</a>, and I always feel overworked and behind - this forces me to reflect and realise that, actually, I’m doing pretty well. The problem is my standards, not me!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-11-live-a-life-you-feel-excited-about">Am I excited about what I am currently working on</a>? If not, what can I <em>do </em>about this? Is there something more fun I could be doing?</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find this one <em>super </em>easy to lose track of in the moment, but is a major productivity and happiness drain</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Collecting data on longer term experiments, eg <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/34-learning">trying a new learning style</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Getting things done</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Notice what you’re currently procrastinating about (<a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/32-macro-procrastination">especially things without deadlines</a>!)</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Notice what you’re putting off - what are the open loops in your mind?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My system is to have an hour once a week for doing “life admin” - all the random tiny tasks on my to do list that are never my higher priority</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Having a clear time once a week where I trust that I’ll do it is valuable - it reduces the mental load the rest of the time, because I feel comfortable forgetting about it, and trusting my future self</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find there’s high switching cost to doing tasks - it disrupts my concentration, and sometimes can open new distractions, eg if I open Messenger. Batching this up once a week reduces the switching costs, and means that when I notice a small task when doing something else, I can just add it to my to-do list and move on</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Gratitude - Gratitude is one of the few peer-reviewed interventions that genuinely, actually, reliably works to make you happier. But if you’re anything like me, it’s not your default. So set yourself time once a week to notice what you’re grateful for, to <em>make </em>it the default! (<a href="https://thezvi.wordpress.com/2017/12/02/more-dakka/">A great post on this</a>)</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Planning the week ahead</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">More generally, I find it highly valuable to separate <strong>planning </strong>and <strong>doing</strong>. I find it much easier to do something concrete, and clearly planned, so I don’t feel the need to waste energy questioning whether what I am doing is worthwhile in the moment. And it’s much easier to plan something, without the imminent prospect of actually <em>doing </em>it forcing me to procrastinate</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So having a first draft of a concrete plan for the next week, can help me become much more focused!</p></li></ul></li></ul><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My implementation</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I currently do my weekly review first thing on Saturday morning, and do it by following a Google Form (you can make a copy of my current form <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/u/0/d/1dxIdbLkS_Vv73C91KKS0uUCqpUv9xdULsH11afLhPxc/copy">here</a>) - I put in the questions and prompts I want to follow, and then just fill out the form. I am a really, really big fan of Google Forms for things like this - they are a super flexible medium to set an algorithm for my future self, and reduce following that algorithm to just filling out boxes. It creates a <em>super </em>clear default action! When I previously tried things like having a list of questions in a word document, I found it easy to start reordering and skipping questions, and getting easily distracted. And they’re easy to edit, so it’s easy to iterate, remove the bad questions, add new habits to my scaffold, etc.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I swap the questions in the form in and out, depending on what’s currently going on in my life, what I am currently finding useful, etc. But these are the parts I’ve consistently found most useful:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Weekly gratitude practice - I go through my calendar for everyone I talked to this week, notice all the interactions I feel excited-in-hindsight about, write them a thank you note detailing what, specifically, I valued about the interaction, and send it to them</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is far and away the most fun part of the review, and is one of the points that really helps the habit stick. Of all of my systems, this is one of my strongest recommendations for other people to try! I think we all have <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-10-seek-positive-externalities">a systematic bias about improving the lives of the people we care about</a>, and this is a small way to overcome that</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It significantly improves my mood, by getting me to dwell on all of the awesome people in my life. And, especially, trying to put into words what specific things I liked about what they did, rather than just sending a vague thanks</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">People often seem concerned that this will feel forced, or make other people feel awkward, or make me seem insincere, but I haven’t encountered any of these issues. The key is that the system isn’t about <em>forcing </em>gratitude - the point is to think about things that happened, and only write a message for the ones where I feel sincere gratitude. And people universally react positively to the message</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It’s also really useful! When I eg meet someone new who I really like, sending a thank you message is an excellent way to signal “I like you and would enjoy keeping in touch”. And this remains sincere, because I rarely want to keep in touch with someone I <em>didn’t </em>enjoy talking to</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Noticing my biggest bottleneck, and spending 5 minutes trying to solve it</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I also do the same for my current Hamming Problem - I think of my biggest bottleneck as a short-term, local problem this week, while my Hamming Problem is my current biggest problem in my life more generally. I find it helpful to both zoom in and zoom out like this</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Braindumping whatever is on my mind - what did I talk to people about this week? What felt like the biggest things that happened? What weighed on my mind? This creates a fun record to look back on</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Following the review with an hour of doing small things on my to-do list, and maintaining my social life</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Asking “what am I currently being an idiot about?” - I find this is a surprisingly effective prompt for eg, things I am procrastinating about, people I should be asking for help</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Tracking progress and successes - what was a win this week? What research progress did I make? </p></li></ul><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Is this worth your time?</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">At this point in the post, I’ve hopefully sketched out what a good regular review <em>could </em>look like. But this kind of thing is also effort - setting up and maintaining a routine is hard in the short-term, and even if it works, it’s a consistent drain on your time. So a natural question is, is it worth your time?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think that for most people reading this who don’t currently do a regular review, the answer is overwhelmingly yes. If you’re the kind of person who reads this blog, agrees with the core insight that <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-7-problems-are-for-fixing">your problems <em>are </em>fixable</a>, and that life <em>could </em>be better, but aren’t sure what to actually <em>do </em>about this, I think this is an excellent place to start. Improving your life isn’t a single flash of inspiration where you realise how to resolve your core problem. It’s a slow, incremental process of noticing problems, trying to fix them, iterating, and slowly making progress. And slow, incremental progress is <em>really </em>powerful in the longterm</p></div></div><div class="sqs-block image-block sqs-block-image" data-block-type="5" id="block-yui_3_17_2_1_1607932582726_14378"><div class="sqs-block-content">
