                image-block-wrapper
                
          
        
                has-aspect-ratio
              "
              data-animation-role="image"
              
  

          >
            <noscript><img src="https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5ed9272a58c63e6402d3fefb/1607938640309-NIWWJIY3S1217BZCBOQB/ke17ZwdGBToddI8pDm48kHldqyjDwaeS7kYSmaCmglZ7gQa3H78H3Y0txjaiv_0fDoOvxcdMmMKkDsyUqMSsMWxHk725yiiHCCLfrh8O1z5QHyNOqBUUEtDDsRWrJLTmTl_ALRZE0UkEheIF40jl8l-p-UjEfP0lrs6khMOijucIE9LbemCnC0mKIu4O-BCA/tiny-gains-graph.jpg" alt="What success looks like" /></noscript><img class="thumb-image" data-src="https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5ed9272a58c63e6402d3fefb/1607938640309-NIWWJIY3S1217BZCBOQB/ke17ZwdGBToddI8pDm48kHldqyjDwaeS7kYSmaCmglZ7gQa3H78H3Y0txjaiv_0fDoOvxcdMmMKkDsyUqMSsMWxHk725yiiHCCLfrh8O1z5QHyNOqBUUEtDDsRWrJLTmTl_ALRZE0UkEheIF40jl8l-p-UjEfP0lrs6khMOijucIE9LbemCnC0mKIu4O-BCA/tiny-gains-graph.jpg" data-image="https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5ed9272a58c63e6402d3fefb/1607938640309-NIWWJIY3S1217BZCBOQB/ke17ZwdGBToddI8pDm48kHldqyjDwaeS7kYSmaCmglZ7gQa3H78H3Y0txjaiv_0fDoOvxcdMmMKkDsyUqMSsMWxHk725yiiHCCLfrh8O1z5QHyNOqBUUEtDDsRWrJLTmTl_ALRZE0UkEheIF40jl8l-p-UjEfP0lrs6khMOijucIE9LbemCnC0mKIu4O-BCA/tiny-gains-graph.jpg" data-image-dimensions="1400x1400" data-image-focal-point="0.5,0.5" alt="What success looks like" data-load="false" data-image-id="5fd7324f102ca46975fdc640" data-type="image" />
          </div>
        
          
        

        
          
          <figcaption class="image-caption-wrapper">
            <div class="image-caption"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What success looks like</p></div>
          </figcaption>
        
      
        </figure>
      

    </div>
  


  


</div></div><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-yui_3_17_2_1_1607932582726_14690"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But it is <em>not </em>the default. For me, a regular review is a cornerstone habit, upon which I can build everything else. Once I <em>see </em>a mistake, fixing it is comparatively easy, but I need to have a routine that forces me to <em>look </em>for them. One friend of mine claims to have completely turned his life around over the past year, and thinks having a regular review was the core of this. There were always failures, off weeks, and times he just didn’t care enough. But the important part was having a safety net, a routine that always got him to <em>return </em>to caring about things</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I expect that for <em>some</em> people this is overkill, but only if you feel like you already do this well enough, without the routine. And I think that that’s pretty rare.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If, at this point, you feel convinced that this <em>could </em>be a good idea, but feel unsure, then I suggest re-framing this as an <strong>experiment</strong>! You’re uncertain about whether regular reviewing is a good idea, and it would be valuable to reduce that uncertainty. <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk">Seek upside risk</a>! Make a plan for a weekly review, and make yourself stick to it for the next 3 weeks. And at the end of that, see whether it felt useful - if it did you can continue doing it and get value over the rest of your life, if it didn’t you can just forget about it, with a bit of time and effort wasted. The benefits <em>massively </em>outweigh the costs. And, at least personally, I find that both the enthusiastic and skeptical parts of me can get behind running an experiment - it reframes the problem from “reviews are definitely awesome” to “I want to reduce my uncertainty”. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Further, it’s <em>hard </em>to be confident a review would be useless, without trying it. The benefits are slow and incremental, and we have a systematic bias against noticing the benefits of gradual, exponential growth. Especially when it takes time away from my “urgent”, short-term concerns, that I know I rarely care about a month from now. The only way to resolve a bias like this is to go out, gather data, and <em>try </em>things!</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And finally, the goal is not to have a perfect review the <em>first </em>time, this is something you can always improve and iterate. If there’s a 50% chance any given question is worth doing, you can just delete the half that aren’t useful! I’ve deliberately given a ton of prompts in this post, I expect some to be helpful and some to be irrelevant. And you can resolve this by trying and seeing. The question is not whether you could design an excellent review <em>now</em>, but whether it would be useful after several rounds of iteration, which is <em>much </em>easier. And something you can only figure out by trying and seeing!</p><h4 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Conclusion</h4><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Overall, I think regular reviews are extremely valuable. Your life <em>will </em>be full of mistakes, and things that could be better. Your goal is not to <em>avoid </em>this, your goal should be to slowly notice them and then actually <em>do </em>something about it. This is not the default, but you can <em>make </em>it the default. And this can form a cornerstone habit - a source of gradual, incremental growth, a scaffold to peg other things to, a way to notice the wasted motion in your life, and <em>do </em>something about it.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And if you’ve gotten to this part of the article, and buy my case that this is worth trying, implement it! I suggest that you set a <a href="https://www.google.com/search?q=5%20minute%20timer">5 minute timer</a> <strong>right now</strong>, and make a start on implementing this routine - pick a time, put it in your calendar, set yourself a reminder, and start to brainstorm good questions. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Imagine it’s a month from now, and you’ve never got round to doing a review. Are you surprised by this outcome? If not, what are you going to do about it?</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">
  
    <span class="author-avatar content-fill" data-tweaks="tweak-show-blog-item-author-profile">
      <img class="author-avatar-image" data-controller="AuthorProfileImageLoader" data-src="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-image="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-load="false" alt="" />
    </span>
  
  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>

          </div>

        About
      </a>
    </div>

      <main id="page" class="container" role="main">
        
          <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">
  
    <section
  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"
  class='page-section
    
      content-collection
      full-bleed-section
      collection-type-blog-basic-grid
    
    background-width--full-bleed
    
      section-height--medium
    
    
      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
    &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
    &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
    &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
    &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
    &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
    &quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,

  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 38: On Slack - Having room to be excited</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Oct 10" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Oct 10</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-5f81c8c1f3350a0e2633fa9e"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-24d833dafb923feafd2b"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Slack</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A few months ago, I came across a concept called <strong>Slack</strong>, and I have found this an increasingly valuable lens for understanding my life. Slack is, roughly, having <strong>spare capacity </strong>in my life. Not being pushed to my limits. Having downtime and room to explore. Being robust to small risks. Not feeling constantly stressed and anxious, having things weighing on my mind. In this post, I’m going to explore the concept of Slack, why the default state of the world is to <em>lack </em>slack, why this matters, and some thoughts on what to do about this.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I first came across the concept in this <a href="https://thezvi.wordpress.com/2017/09/30/slack/">post</a> by Zvi, and it’s written fairly abstractly. And for good reason! I’ve struggled to articulate precisely what the concept really <em>is</em>. So, to see whether this resonates, here are some examples of what having Slack looks like:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If an urgent task comes up, you can reprioritise, put off your current work, and take care of it</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you’re tired and have spent the morning getting nothing done, this is fine. You can stop working early, take a long break, write the day off entirely, and get back to things tomorrow</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you come across something <em>awesome</em>, you can put off what you’re currently doing to take a few hours to dive deeply into it, and see what comes out of it</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you have an unexpected expense - you break something expensive, fall ill, etc - it’s not a big deal, your savings can absorb it</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think Slack is an <em>incredibly </em>important component of having a life worth living! Having Slack gives you <strong>freedom</strong>. You have room to explore, be spontaneous and try new things. You have room to zoom out, reflect on your life, <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-7-problems-are-for-fixing">notice problems and fix them</a>. You can take the time and energy to break out of whatever <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-22-the-8020-rule">bad local optima</a> you’re stuck in. You can <em>relax</em> - life always contains risks and setbacks, but you know that you’ll be able to deal with them when they arise. You can be free of constant short-term anxiety.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’m labouring this point, because <strong>the default state of the world is that your life lacks Slack</strong>. It is obvious that Slack is important when phrased like this - zoomed out, in the abstract. But Slack is defined as <strong>something you can spend</strong>. There is a delicate balance between being willing to <em>use </em>your Slack where appropriate, but also realising that it is a quantity worth treasuring - something to cherish, prioritise and guard.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And there are times when it is exceptionally hard to have Slack! Due to life circumstances, like illness or money problems. By choice, eg by choosing to do an intensive job or degree for long-term reward. But I think there are also many times where Slack is spent needlessly. Where you <em>always </em>allocate your spare capacity away to the next priority, always trying to make your life optimal in the moment. Without noticing the bottlenecks you’re creating, and what you’re giving up. And this post is aimed at noticing ways you <em>waste </em>your Slack, making it clearer what you’re giving up, and seeing if it’s really worth it.</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Units of Exchange</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Digressing somewhat from Slack, a related lens I find useful is the idea of <strong>units of exchange</strong>. We often think of our lives in terms of quantifiable resources, such as time and money. This is valuable, because we often trade-off between these two resources, by trading one for the other, and tracking resource costs can tell us whether it was a good trade! For example, often jobs are just a way to trade time and labour for money. Going the other way, we often pay money to save time. For example, I made this website with Squarespace and pay a fair bit more for that than a free alternative, but I save a <em>lot </em>of time due to things just working.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The idea of units of exchange is to introduce more <strong>abstract </strong>resources. Harder to quantify but important things, such as energy, willpower, sleep, focused time, attention, health, etc. Everything we do in life is a trade-off, but often we’re trading these more abstract resources too, and thinking about them can make it clear what the <em>actual </em>trade off is. Examples:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’d pay for an Uber home rather than taking the time to walk if late at night, but not during the day - during the day I’m trading money for <strong>time</strong>, at night I’m trading money for <strong>sleep</strong></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’d prefer to take a train to work than drive, even if it takes longer, because I can take the time on the train to read or get work done - the true trade isn’t for <strong>time</strong>, it’s for <strong>productive time</strong></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I turn off all notifications when I’m working - it takes the same amount of <strong>time </strong>to respond now vs later, but the real cost is to my <strong>attention </strong>and <strong>focus</strong></p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This mindset can sound obvious at first, but it’s often insightful when trying to diagnose a problem. For example, when I feel overwhelmed and stressed, the right solution depends a lot on which resource I lack! Maybe I just don’t have enough <strong>time</strong>, and can resolve this by quitting something, or being less social. Maybe I don’t have enough <strong>sleep</strong>, so I’m being extremely unproductive in the time I do have, and I can resolve this with better discipline around bedtimes and not staying up. Maybe I’m too <strong>stressed</strong>, and I really need to focus on the root cause of what’s stressing me out so I can relax more.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Units of exchange can be hard to think about, because they’re difficult to quantify - we can’t just calculate exchange rates like we can with money and time, they’re too abstract. But often this isn’t decision relevant. Often the important thing is identifying <strong>bottlenecks </strong>- the resource(s) that I spend too much of, and don’t have enough of when I need them. And <em>this </em>is where units of exchange help us to understand Slack better. <strong>Your Slack is constrained by your tightest bottleneck</strong>. To really have Slack, you want to have spare capacity in <em>all </em>of your resources - enough energy and rest to pursue your interests, enough time to spare, enough willpower and attention to keep focused, enough money to be able to relax and try things.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And, accordingly, if you <em>find </em>a bottleneck, <strong>fixing this should be your priority</strong>. This is likely one of the biggest constraints on your life and your Slack. Notice where you spend it in your life, and ask whether you feel happy with this allocation. Ask yourself where you can cut back. If it’s money, look at your budget. If it’s time, think about your biggest commitments and time sinks, and think about what you least value. If it’s sleep, think about your sleep routine. If it’s willpower, think about the systems in your life. The question is not whether you can afford to give something up. You’re <em>already </em>giving up your Slack. The question is whether what you’d have to give up to fix it is better than what you’re <em>already </em>giving up. Everything is a trade-off</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it valuable at this point to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">think in systems</a>. It’s easy to notice a bottleneck and resolve to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-6-stop-pressing-the-try-harder-button">Try Harder</a> and fix it. But your resources are spent in day-to-day life, bit by bit. If there is one big fix, then that’s awesome! Eg, an unnecessary time commitment you can just quit. But often the problem is from the <strong>default actions </strong>you take. Eg, bleeding attention away every time your phone buzzes. And the only sustainable solution is to <strong>change the default</strong>.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise</strong>: Think about the abstract resources in <em>your </em>life. What feels like a bottleneck? What is holding you back? What feels missing? And once you’ve found one, think about how you <em>spend </em>it. Is there anywhere you could cut back? Are you happy with this allocation, and the Slack it costs you? </p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Naive Optimisation</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another failure to have Slack that I personally resonate with a lot stems from <strong>perfectionism</strong>, and a neurotic desire to “optimise” my life - what I call naive optimisation<strong>.</strong></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’m a very big fan of <em>true </em>optimisation - which I consider to be defining goals, identifying the actions that best achieve those goals, and shaping my life so that the default path is to <em>take </em>those actions. I think this is awesome, and a big component of my personal growth over the past few years. But as I talk about <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-9-what-it-means-to-optimise">in this post</a>, there’s a failure mode of <strong>naive optimisation</strong> that I find it easy to fall into. Where there’s a neurotic voice in my head that, in every moment, uses guilt and stress to push me towards whatever action seems best in the moment.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And naive optimisation is terrible, because this inner voice is <em>full </em>of biases! It doesn’t account for the <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk">value of information and trying new things, that <em>could </em>go awesomely</a>. It always needs to be in control, and fears vulnerability and risk. It’s a perfectionist, and holds me to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/35-standards">unrealistically high standards</a>. It takes energy to ignore, and is very hard to ever properly turn off.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But, for the purposes of this article this is important because <strong>naive optimisation will burn away your Slack</strong>. Slack is something to be guarded and protected to help with risks, to take opportunities, to respond to unknown unknowns. To embrace Slack is to inherently give up some aspect of control in my life. Slack is always precious, but rarely feels <em>necessary</em>. And so the neurotic voice in my head always wants to give it up. To be an overachiever, and take that extra course, since I <em>obviously </em>have time for it. To say yes to that extra commitment. To feel bad and guilty when I have time for rest, and am not pushing myself to my limits.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Needless to say, <strong>this is terrible</strong>. This mindset is a significant impediment to having an awesome and fulfilling life. Even without any true hard constraints, listening to the naive optimiser can burn away all of my Slack, without me ever realising what I’m giving up. Further, <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/31-overcoming-bias"><strong>this is a bias</strong></a><strong>. </strong>You fundamentally cannot trust yourself, in the moment, to properly protect and cherish your Slack, you need to have some form of manual override. Build systems to protect your Slack. Budget yourself time for things, and <em>keep </em>to it. Schedule yourself downtime, and make it feel <strong>sacrosanct</strong>. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find this mindset similar to the one needed to take <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/29-meaningful-rest">meaningful rest</a>. It’s never <em>necessary </em>to take a break. And, for any <em>single </em>break, I might get more done if I don’t take it! And I often won’t feel like I <em>need </em>rest when it’s time to take a break. But if, on a policy level, I systematically don’t take enough breaks, then I get stressed, tired, unfocused and get <em>way </em>less done. So I need to overcome this systematic bias, create a manual override, and make the default action to take breaks even if it feels unnecessary. And that I can’t just listen to the naive optimiser in my head if I really want to win. Just so when it comes to preserving my Slack.</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Motivation</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another area of my life that is extremely important to me is motivation. Specifically, the divide between <strong>intrinsic </strong>motivation - doing things because I <em>want </em>to, because I feel excited about them and driven - and <strong>extrinsic </strong>motivation - doing things because I have to, driving myself with guilt and obligation. And an ongoing quest is <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/35-standards">getting over the crutch of using extrinsic motivation for everything</a>, and <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-11-live-a-life-you-feel-excited-about">cultivating a life full of intrinsic motivation</a>. Generally, I find intrinsic motivation far more fun and far more useful, but also far more fragile and easily lost, while extrinsic motivation is often easy and available, but rarely as effective as it could be.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And this is important in the context of Slack, because when I have <em>low </em>Slack, I feel like I need to <strong>try hard</strong>. Things feel scarce, I can’t afford to slack off, or take enough breaks. I need to push myself, and optimise. I need to pull out all the standard, available tools of guilt, obligation, unrealistic standards. I need to be in control. My life is driven by the voice of the naive optimiser, and I fall deep into extrinsic motivation. And, even if in reality, I <em>do </em>have Slack, so long as the naive optimiser is in control, I’ll still be stuck on this crutch of guilt based motivation.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>Intrinsic </em>motivation, on the other hand is characterised by play, curiosity and exploration. Doing something because I <em>want</em> to, not because I <em>have </em>to. This can often be far more fulfilling <em>and </em>far more productive, but there is an inherent lack of control here. I need to be able to zoom out and give myself the <em>room </em>to explore. I can’t let the inner optimiser control every last detail of what I’m doing. <strong>To have intrinsic motivation, I must first have Slack</strong>. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To me, this highlights well the notion of Slack as <strong>spare capacity</strong>, the ability to <strong>break out of bad local optima</strong>. If I’m pushing myself hard, I am stuck in a local optima. It feels <em>wrong</em> to stop, to slack off. <em>Even though </em>doing this well could give me the room to feel excited about what I’m doing, and get far more done in the long-run, I must first have enough Slack to <em>stop</em> and reconsider.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is an <em>extremely </em>salient problem to me at the moment, because I’m spending the next 3 months trying out academic research. And research is characterised by exploration, following curiosity, trying things and seeing what works. But it’s <em>so </em>easy to slip into the trap of guilt and obligation, to set myself unrealistic standards, and then push myself to meet them, without really giving myself the room to enjoy what I’m doing. (Suggestions on how to address this problem in research would be very highly appreciated!)</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise: </strong>Where do you use extrinsic motivation and guilt in your life? Are you happy with this? Have you given yourself the Slack to take a step away and try another approach?</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Whimsy</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think there is an <em>excellent </em>utilitarian argument for the use of intrinsic motivation, and I feel confident it’s far more effective in the long-term. But this mindset feels like using extrinsic motivation to <em>force </em>myself to feel intrinsic motivation, which I think is doomed to failure. When aiming for an ambitious change like this, I try to imagine a future where I <em>have </em>achieved the change, and ask myself to explain how this happened. And I cannot imagine that change happening by thinking about how <em>useful</em> intrinsic motivation is, or how I really <em>ought </em>to feel it more often. Instead, I think the core skill for intrinsic motivation is to <strong>pursue something for its own sake</strong>. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">There is a particular mindset I sometimes slip into, at the times when I do feel intrinsic motivation, that feels characteristic of a flow state. Where I’m not focused on long-term goals, and am living in the moment. Where I’m introspecting, in touch with the subtle hints of curiosity and excitement in my mind. Where I’m following this sense of curiosity and drive, pursuing whatever seems most exciting in the moment, and loving what I’m currently doing. I call this state of mind <strong>whimsy </strong>- being in touch with my emotions and my whims, in touch with what I really care, and following those where they lead. And I think that getting good at this mindset is key to a reliable source of intrinsic motivation.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is not a mindset that comes to me particularly naturally, but the times when I have felt it have often been the most productive <em>and </em>more fun times I can remember. And I think this is a <em>trainable </em>skill - both one where I can practice slipping into the mindset, and where <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-11-live-a-life-you-feel-excited-about">I can learn how to shape my life to encourage it</a>. And it’s a skill that is <em>extremely </em>worth some short-term costs training, if I build it better into my life in the long-term. My ideal life wouldn’t be 100% pursuing whimsy, but it would be a fairly large long-term component.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And this isn’t a skill that can be trained by just trying harder. The main approach I’ve found is to give myself regular space for it, and see what happens. For the last few months, I’ve been calling my Sunday afternoons my <strong>Afternoons of Whimsy</strong>, keeping them clear, and ensuring this routine feels <strong>sacrosanct </strong>- something precious that I am unwilling to give up easily. And in this time, I am not allowed to care about my long-term goals, or my various obligations. This is time carved out to introspect, find out what I feel <em>excited </em>about doing, and pursue it. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">As I said, this is something that I struggle with, and not something that comes naturally. Sometimes I’m tired and fall into a spiral of procrastination, and do a range of un-rejuvenating things like scrolling endlessly through Reddit. Sometimes I fail to keep out my long-term goals, and end up feeling obliged to do my current highest priority and trick myself into considering it “fun”. But sometimes I feel a whim to do something <em>fun</em>, that I wouldn’t normally take joy in. Like going for a spontaneous run through a thunderstorm, or cleaning up my room while singing along to Disney songs. Sometimes I feel a whim to do something cool and virtuous for its own sake -  like watching lectures from an online course I’m finding interesting, writing a spontaneous blog post, trying to code up something cool, or reading a textbook on something I want to understand more deeply. Maybe one in two or three afternoons I do something really <em>awesome</em> in hindsight. But in another sense, this isn’t the point. I don’t <em>care </em>about exactly what I get done - this is time I carve out where the best way to achieve my long-term goals is to <em>not </em>care about them. And so feeling regret about how it goes is missing the point. I feel confident that I’m slowly improving at the mindset of whimsy, and <em>that </em>is the best way to achieve my long-term goals</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If this idea resonates with you, some tips:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you’re feeling somewhat sold on the problem I’ve outlined, but skeptical at actually dedicating so much time to this solution, <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk">seek upside risk</a> and try it! If it works well, this is <em>awesome</em>, something you can keep doing, and could significant help with a major life bug. If not, you can just give up, at the cost of a few afternoons spent doing fun things</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is an experiment in pursuit of a long-term goal, so it is something you want to do long-term! Build a system around it, and make it feel <strong>sacrosanct</strong>. I make mine Sunday afternoons, both because Sunday is a natural time for a period of rest, and because this is a regular routine, that can help me protect and cherish it.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Leave yourself a long time! I find that 3 hours minimum is often necessary - I might feel a bit lazy at the start, procrastinate for a while, but then feel a whim to do something cool. </p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Try not to plan too hard in advance - early on I found myself in the failure mode of planning what to do that afternoon in the morning, and in the moment it felt a bit stale, but I tried to push through anyway</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">My current approach is to go for a walk at the start and clear my head. Then to make a wish list - set a <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers">5 minute timer</a>, then write down anything that pops into my head that I could do, and the moment I find something that grabs me, stop writing and run with it!  And if nothing seems fun, go do something else</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Remember, the goal isn’t to find the <em>best </em>thing - that’s the naive optimiser talking. You want to find something <em>fun, </em>and the moment something grabs you you should run with it!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it helpful to write tasks down as “I could read …?” “I could watch …?”. It is <em>fine </em>if I spend this afternoon doing absolutely nothing, and writing these as <strong>wishes</strong> anchors me to doing nothing - now anything I achieve is an upside! I otherwise find it easy to slip into the mindset of writing down a long list and getting sad at what you’re missing out on by not doing everything - anchoring yourself to doing <em>everything. </em></p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Be willing to give up on things - if you aren’t enjoying what you’re doing in the moment, switch to something else!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Keep in mind that it’s <em>fine </em>to get nothing done - don’t put pressure on yourself</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The spirit of whimsy, at least for me, isn’t <em>quite </em>doing whatever I want. It’s about noticing and <strong>nurturing </strong>the feeling of excitement. If I feel drawn to something, focusing on why its <em>awesome</em>. Encouraging myself to pursue it, thinking about the upside, not about the risks and costs</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Overall I’ve found this a great routine to have in my life. I think rest is an important component of my life, but it’s easy for all of my rest to just be a <a href="https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/ximou2kyQorm6MPjX/rest-days-vs-recovery-days">recovery period</a> - something I do in the evening after a day of work, when I feel tired and drained, and just want to switch off and recharge. My afternoons of whimsy are done when I have <em>energy</em> - where I can pursue things I actually care about. Where things still feel somewhat like work, and still take some energy, but feel fulfilling enough that I get out more energy than I put in. Where I can find the work-shaped things in my life that feel intrinsically worth doing for their own sake, and remind myself that I actually care about them.</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Conclusion</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In conclusion, Slack is an <em>incredibly </em>important resource! It’s a major component of my overall life happiness. If you aren’t explicitly thinking about it, the first step is just to realise that Slack is meaningful and important, and something to value, and to notice if your life lacks it. To guard and protect the Slack that you do have, and to carve out more if you don’t have enough.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A necessary condition for having enough Slack is not being <em>bottlenecked </em> - think of your life in terms of units of exchange, and notice if anything feels missing or constraining. And if you find a bottleneck, fixing that should be a major priority! How can you shift the default of your life to better preserve that resource?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A further necessary condition is to <em>relax</em>. To resist the call of the naive optimiser, to resist the urge to squeeze out every last drop of optimality in your life, and to realise that <em>true </em>optimality is this fuzzy, imprecise balance. That to <em>truly </em>be optimal, you can’t fully be in control, and can’t be trying as hard as possible.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Having enough Slack, and cultivating this skill is a key component of getting intrinsic motivation and drive! Which, if you’re anything like me, won’t come very naturally, but is a really important skill, and one worth putting meaningful effort into. And a way I recommend to pursue this, is to explicitly carve out time to <em>practice </em>having intrinsic motivation and whimsy - to do things for their own sake, to let go of outside concerns and obligations, and to follow your own sense of curiosity.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Are you happy with the amount of Slack in your life? And if not, what could bring you closer to a world with more Slack? And how could you <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-21-taking-the-first-step">take the first step</a> in that direction?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>If the ideas in this post resonated, related reading I’d recommend: Zvi on </em><a href="https://thezvi.wordpress.com/2017/09/30/slack/"><em>Slack</em></a><em>, Jacob Falkovich linking </em><a href="https://putanumonit.com/2017/11/07/confessions-of-a-slacker/"><em>Slack and Units of Exchange</em></a><em>, some </em><a href="https://dynalist.io/d/pgngbu6nDQbQzu1Gcof3Dj1i#z=pznohefw9903y9277WlU56fW"><em>notes for a workshop I wrote covering Units of Exchange</em></a><em>, SlateStarCodex on </em><a href="https://slatestarcodex.com/2020/05/12/studies-on-slack/"><em>the importance of Slack</em></a><em>. And if the ideas on extrinsic motivation resonated, I’d </em>highly <em>recommend </em><a href="http://mindingourway.com/guilt"><em>the Replacing Guilt series by Nate Soares</em></a></p><p class="" data-rte-preserve-empty="true" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">

id="linkedin-unauth-icon" viewBox="0 0 64 64"><path d="M20.4,44h5.4V26.6h-5.4V44z M23.1,18c-1.7,0-3.1,1.4-3.1,3.1c0,1.7,1.4,3.1,3.1,3.1 c1.7,0,3.1-1.4,3.1-3.1C26.2,19.4,24.8,18,23.1,18z M39.5,26.2c-2.6,0-4.4,1.4-5.1,2.8h-0.1v-2.4h-5.2V44h5.4v-8.6 c0-2.3,0.4-4.5,3.2-4.5c2.8,0,2.8,2.6,2.8,4.6V44H46v-9.5C46,29.8,45,26.2,39.5,26.2z"/></symbol><symbol id="linkedin-unauth-mask" viewBox="0 0 64 64"><path d="M0,0v64h64V0H0z M25.8,44h-5.4V26.6h5.4V44z M23.1,24.3c-1.7,0-3.1-1.4-3.1-3.1c0-1.7,1.4-3.1,3.1-3.1 c1.7,0,3.1,1.4,3.1,3.1C26.2,22.9,24.8,24.3,23.1,24.3z M46,44h-5.4v-8.4c0-2,0-4.6-2.8-4.6c-2.8,0-3.2,2.2-3.2,4.5V44h-5.4V26.6 h5.2V29h0.1c0.7-1.4,2.5-2.8,5.1-2.8c5.5,0,6.5,3.6,6.5,8.3V44z"/></symbol></svg>

      <main id="page" class="container" role="main">
        
          <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">
  
    <section
  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"
  class='page-section
    
      content-collection
      full-bleed-section
      collection-type-blog-basic-grid
    
    background-width--full-bleed
    
      section-height--medium
    
    
      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
  &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
  &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
  &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
  &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
  &quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,
  &quot;contentWidth&quot;: &quot;content-width--wide&quot;,
  &quot;customContentWidth&quot;: 50,
  &quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;light&quot;,
  &quot;sectionAnimation&quot;: &quot;none&quot;,
  &quot;backgroundMode&quot;: &quot;image&quot;
}"
  data-animation="none"

  <div class="section-background">

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 33: Seek Upside Risk</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Sep 29" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Sep 29</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-5f73487f3e312c6ef8ae169c"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-f0087492ed51eb9d1f5c"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">When I meet somebody new, there are two interesting things that could happen. We could get on <em>super </em>well, become great friends, and be part of each other’s lives for year to come. Or we don’t. Maybe we like each other, maybe we don’t, but we likely just go our separate ways. But the upside in the first case <em>massively </em>outweighs the downside in the second case. Yet, we all spend far less time meeting new people than we could. Why?</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Upside Risk</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I call this general phenomena of a small chance of a massive win, vs a reasonable chance of a tiny loss, <strong>upside risk</strong>. And when I think about some of the <em>really awesome </em>things in my life, a lot of it came from sources of upside risk:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I have a lot of <em>amazing </em>friends, most of whom I went <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-23-taking-social-initiative">out of my way to meet and keep in touch with</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Hobbies! I tried blogging, it might have been a bit of a waste of time, but <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/27-retrospective">turned out to be fucking awesome</a>. I could have lost a bit of time, but I now have a great new creative outlet!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Asking for advice and favours - I’m going to be spending the next 3 months doing a research project, and this would never have happened if I hadn’t been asking loads of people for advice and suggestions!</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In general, I think there are a <em>lot </em>of sources of upside risk in life, and that they’re extremely positive in expectation. And if you do enough of them, this pays out well. So I think it’s <em>extremely </em>valuable to actively seek out upside risk, and to shape your life to welcome it. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">There’s even a fairly solid mathematical justification for this! This is known as the <strong>explore/exploit problem</strong> in reinforcement learning - do I <strong>exploit</strong> and do what I currently think is the best idea, or do I <strong>explore</strong> and try something new, something that might give me <strong>information</strong><em> </em>that I can use to inform future actions. The problem is essentially pricing the value of information. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And a pretty decent (and easy-to-compute) strategy is to take the <a href="https://lilianweng.github.io/lil-log/2018/01/23/the-multi-armed-bandit-problem-and-its-solutions.html#upper-confidence-bounds"><strong>Upper Confidence Bound</strong></a>. We have uncertainty over each strategy, and pick the strategy with the highest 95% confidence bound. Essentially, it pays to be an optimist, to always take the action with the best chance of being <em>awesome</em>. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This post is going to be about why we <em>don’t </em>seek upside risk as much as we could, and how we can change this.</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Becoming emotionally OK with it</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So, this is a pretty simple argument. Yet, I do this far less than I could. Why?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The root cause, is that my mind <em>sucks </em>at thinking about expected values. When I try something new, the <strong>cost</strong><em> </em>is clear, concrete and salient. The <strong>benefit </strong>is fuzzy, distant and unclear. And so if I try it and only get the cost, it feels like I <strong>failed</strong>. Hindsight bias kicks in, and it feels <em>obvious </em>that it wasn’t worth trying. The subtle, insidious voice of insecurity in my head pushes me to play it safe, not stick my neck out, to not risk it. That it’s not worth the effort, and things will never work out well. I’m a loss averse person, and I can’t see a <em>guaranteed </em>story for how this upside will pay out, so it feels not worth reaching for.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think this is one of the most poisonous and damaging bugs currently in my life. I think this <em>significantly </em>cuts off a lot of awesome potential in my life. So <strong>fuck that. </strong>I don’t <em>need </em>a precise story for how to get this upside, I just need to expose myself to as much as possible. So how can I reframe this and <em>do </em>something about it?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some of my favourite strategies:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong><em>Make </em>the upside concrete</strong>: Try to flesh out a concrete scenario where this goes awesomely. Imagine it’s in the 90th percentile of awesome, what happened? Add as many specific details and ideas as possible. And if the creeping voice of insecurity in your head triggers, remember that it’s <em>explicitly </em>a hypothetical where everything goes well, so you can ignore it!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And now, at the end, do you feel any more excited about this upside?</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Think in expected value</strong>: When I’m trying something new, I’m operating in a position of uncertainty. I need to choose based on the expected value (EV). But <em>afterwards </em>I know the actualised value. And if I don’t stop myself, hindsight bias creeps in, and it feels <em>obvious </em>that I should have known that all along.<br>But, if I’m trying to update what I do in future, this is dumb! All future choices are made based on EV, so that’s what I should actually care about. So keep score in EV! If you took a bunch of positive EV actions and are confident it was the right call, focus on that, not on the statistical noise of the results</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is awesome, because it <em>redefines failure</em>. If I take a positive EV action that goes wrong, who cares! I still won</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’ve thought about this mindset enough that I’m now happy if I ask somebody out and am rejected - the action was still positive EV!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Alternate framing: Focus on the <strong>value of information</strong>. If I try swing dancing and it sucks, this is <em>great</em>! I learned something new about myself, and need never try swing dancing again</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Strive to become <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/become-a-person-who-actually-does-things">someone who Actually Does Things</a>. Score things by how they shape my future actions and bring me closer to the kind of person I want to be</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Do it for the joy of novelty</strong>: Trying new things is <strong>fun!</strong> I can learn new things! Have new experiences!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find it pretty easy to get joy just from doing something new - satisfying curiosity, learning something new</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If I notice my life in a bit of a rut, I find it super motivating if I can start pushing myself out of it by adding in some novelty</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Just do it</strong>: Have a rule of just <em>doing </em>any low cost, high upside idea. If you have a request you want to make of someone, just do it! If you want to invite a friend to start an ambitious project, just do it!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">For me, insecurities are most insidious when there is <em>uncertainty</em>. When there is a <em>choice</em>. Choices take energy and willpower, and it’s easy for insecurity to massively raise this cost. The beauty of a <em>policy</em><strong> </strong>is that <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower"><strong>changes the default</strong></a>. Figuring out whether it’s worth it isn’t worth the computational resources, just do it!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Policies can build momentum - if you can push yourself through the first few times, it feels aversive to <em>not </em>keep going, because you’re breaking a streak, and screwing over your future self!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This also redefines failure - the goal is to follow the policy, because on average the policy works! Who cares if it doesn’t work sometimes?</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Opportunity framings</strong>: If I’m asking a favour of somebody <em>else</em>, I find it super helpful to frame it as presenting them with an opportunity. If I ask somebody for a job and they say yes, they aren’t doing me a <em>favour</em>, they’re doing it because it’s helpful to them! So, asking in the first place is giving them <strong>free option value</strong>, they can always say no! </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So, when asking for something, think about how it can benefit the <em>other </em>person!</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This can work even when there’s no direct benefit - I generally find it fun to give advice to people, even though I get no benefit from it. Which means at least some of the people who give advice to me enjoy it!</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This relies on the other person being comfortable saying no in a low cost way. Conveniently, this is normally true in the more intimidating scenarios, like asking for a job! And if I’m asking for somebody’s time, the busier and higher status they are, the more they’ll have practiced saying no to things and so the lower cost it’ll be to them.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Conversely, I know that for some of my friends, saying no is hard. So if they say no to an offer I give them, I make a point of congratulating them on practicing the skill of declining things! And this utterly takes the sting out of rejection, and makes it feel lower cost to ask for favours next time :)</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Implementing</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So, say you now agree that upside risk is extremely valuable, and you’ve somewhat overcome the aversion. How can we make this <em>actionable</em>?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">There are a few different ways of framing the core lesson:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Do things that are high variance!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Optimise for the best-case scenario, be an optimist!</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Optimise for information value, what can <em>teach </em>you the most? Do things where if it goes well, you can do it again and again</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Seek novelty</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find seeking novelty to be particularly fruitful. A few ways to do this:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Be willing to try anything once, default to yes. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I try to do this for life hacks/productivity advice - I’ve tried a lot of crap ones that I’ve discarded, but the ones that work well are now a <em>core </em>part of my life. Eg, discovering the value of a consistent routine, and how to use financial accountability right have been phenomenally valuable to me</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"> Make seeking novelty a <strong>quest</strong>. Set a bounded period of your life, say the next 1-2 months, where you are going to go out of your way to do novel things, and see what it’s like. You aren’t trying to evaluate what’s worthwhile or do a cost-benefit analysis, just doing whatever is most fun and feels shiniest</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">When I decided to try this, I went to taster sessions for about 10 societies. And most were crap! But it turns out that gliding, pole-dancing, ceilidh dancing and trampolining are all <em>super </em>awesome</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I also ended up donating blood, learning how to cycle, learning how to bake, among a bunch of other stuff. My life was <em>way </em>more fun that term, and a few things have stuck!</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If something is boring, think about how you could reframe it to <em>make </em>it novel. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">For exams in my second year, I felt obliged to spend 2 months revising, but expected this to be a poor use of my time. So I reframed it to be about trying different ways of learning, and getting information about how I learned best. </p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A few findings:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCzoIa8e4vhfRIxL_Kj6yy0Q?view_as=subscriber">giving talks</a> <em>super </em>motivating and fun, and it holds me to a high standard</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I really enjoy teaching and tutoring, trying to explain content intuitively to other people</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="http://augmentingcognition.com/ltm.html">Spaced repetition</a> is fucking awesome</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://dynalist.io/d/ToOhEKlz9qC2PmpjgyTpXQJz">Making notes</a> with the intent of publishing holds me to a <em>way </em>higher standard (and <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-10-seek-positive-externalities">has positive externalities</a>!)</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">There were a handful of failed experiments too, but I can’t really remember them. And really, I think that summarises this entire post</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The idea of <strong>Comfort Zone Expansion (CoZE)</strong>. Finding things outside your comfort zone, that you’d normally find super aversive, and finding ways to try them in a safe, supportive environment.</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">CFAR have a CoZE section at their workshops, and I found it super valuable every time! I’ve spent CoZE workshops:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Going around a room asking people for sincere criticism, and not becoming defensive</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Asking people for favours (man, I suck at this)</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Having an open, honest and vulnerable conversation with a relative stranger, where we agreed to not deflect or use defence mechanisms (which was the start of becoming <em>way </em>better at this)</p></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another mindset is to optimise for the best-case scenario, which I like to think of as <strong>fishing for white swans</strong>. Some strategies:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">When doing anything, use pre-hindsight. Assume it went <em>phenomenally </em>well, and try to explain what happened? And when you have an explanation, try to <em>make </em>it happen</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">High-variance small talk! The social norm is normally for first meetings to be dull, and keep to safe topics. I generally try to skip to whatever I find interesting - digging into people’s motivations, dreams, stories and fascinations. Getting to something genuinely interesting rapidly <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-5-how-to-learn-from-conversations">seems to be a trainable skill</a></p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I gather this makes me come across as somewhat direct and intense, but the world is full of people! This probably filters out some people I’d have gotten on well with, but has found me a lot of awesome close friends. </p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">When asking for advice, it’s easy to focus on minor uncertainties, and to be scared of asking big questions. But advice is most useful when it <em>radically </em>changes something</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">“What’s a bit of life-changing advice you’ve received?”</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">“What is the biggest problem with my current life plan?”</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">“Suppose in 5 years you realise everything you just told me was wrong. What happened?”</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">“What’s something it could make sense for me to try with <em>super </em>high potential upside?”</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Interestingly, this strategy is often <em>most </em>useful when things are already going well for me. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If I already have a bunch of great friends, I want to filter harder for <em>exceptionally </em>awesome new friends</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If I have a great life plan, I want to try something wild and high-variance, since I’m optimising for the probability of finding something <em>better</em></p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some generic examples of things worth doing:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Going on dates</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Meeting new people</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Applying for jobs and problems that seem out of your league</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Trying a hobby! An instrument, improv comedy, public speaking, blogging. Something outside your comfort zone</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Notice the feeling of reluctance and procrastination, and check whether it feels justified</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Follow the crazy ideas that pop into your head! If you have a wild new idea for a party or event, go ahead and organise it</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It helps to be in an environment that facilitates this kind of thing, I’ve found it pretty useful to be loosely involved in student societies for this</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And these are just my examples! Upside risk is a function of <em>your </em>life, <em>your </em>values, and <em>your </em>circumstances. What are some examples of this in <em>your </em>life?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Exercise: </strong>Set a <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers">5 minute timer</a>, and think about the ideas in this post. What are sources of upside risk <em>you </em>could seek out?</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Conclusion</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Obviously, I’m making an overly strong case in this post. We have finite time, and there are trade-offs. If you <em>always </em>chase upside risk, you’re Pascal’s Mugging yourself out of any free time. Sometimes there are hidden big <em>downside </em>risks. But I see a <em>lot </em>of instances of safe, moderate actions with upside risk that aren’t taken. And, at least in my social circles, I think on the margin people should seek upside risk way more! </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So if the ideas in this post resonated with you, <strong>live it</strong>! Keep score in terms of EV. Seek novelty. Try new things. Go outside your comfort zone. Ask for things. Notice the <em>massive </em>pile of potential wins in your life, and ask whether you’re OK with leaving all of that on the table. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s a source of upside risk you could seek <em>right now</em>?</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">
  
    <span class="author-avatar content-fill" data-tweaks="tweak-show-blog-item-author-profile">

    </span>
  
  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>

M46,44h-5.4v-8.4c0-2,0-4.6-2.8-4.6c-2.8,0-3.2,2.2-3.2,4.5V44h-5.4V26.6 h5.2V29h0.1c0.7-1.4,2.5-2.8,5.1-2.8c5.5,0,6.5,3.6,6.5,8.3V44z"/></symbol></svg>

  </body>

  </g>
</svg>
              <div class="icon-cart-quantity">
                <span class="sqs-cart-quantity">0</span>
              </div>
            </span>
          </a>
        </div>
      

      <header
  data-test="header"
  id="header"
  class='
    dark
    header theme-col--primary
  '
  data-controller="Header"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;layout&quot;: &quot;navLeft&quot;,
  &quot;action&quot;: {
    &quot;buttonText&quot;: &quot;Get Started&quot;,
    &quot;newWindow&quot;: false

  &quot;showSocial&quot;: true,
  &quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;dark&quot;,
