      <main id="page" class="container" role="main">
        
          <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">
  
    <section
  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"
  class='page-section
    
      content-collection
      full-bleed-section
      collection-type-blog-basic-grid
    
    background-width--full-bleed
    
      section-height--medium
    
    
      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
  &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
  &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
  &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
  &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
  &quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,
  &quot;contentWidth&quot;: &quot;content-width--wide&quot;,
  &quot;customContentWidth&quot;: 50,
  &quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;light&quot;,
  &quot;sectionAnimation&quot;: &quot;none&quot;,
  &quot;backgroundMode&quot;: &quot;image&quot;
}"
  data-animation="none"
   
  
    
  
>
  <div class="section-background">
  
    
  
  </div>
  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Post 28: On Creativity - the joys of 5 minute timers</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Aug 16" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Aug 16</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-5f395b84e734c879bcba90be"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-1a1c02f8636e15778a94"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Introduction</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A really common failure mode that I observe in myself and others is to get <em>stuck </em>and then give up. To be working on a problem, or trying to generate ideas, find it hard and stop looking. I find that this goes hand-in-hand with the far larger problem of being trapped within your preconceptions - to notice the obvious solution to your problem, the obvious life path ahead of you, the obvious thing somebody in your role <em>should </em>do, and never realising there can be anything more. I think this is a <em>really </em>big problem, because the world is large and complicated. The space of possibilities is <em>enormous </em>and the ability to search beyond what’s obviously visible is really valuable for noticing when you are <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-22-the-8020-rule">wasting motion</a>. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think these problems are, at their heart, a <strong>lack of creativity</strong>. I think creativity is an incredibly valuable skill and, importantly, a <em>learnable</em> <em>skill</em>, not an inherent trait. This is a skill that I still suck at, but I’ve improved a lot at over time, and this post is my attempt to outline the approach that’s worked best for me.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is obviously a useful skill in settings like doing art and research. But I’ve found it useful in a wide range of areas in my life. A few highlights:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-7-problems-are-for-fixing">Solving personal problems</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Giving advice to others</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Solving the small problems I run into when doing work</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Finding ways to have fun</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Finding projects <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-11-live-a-life-you-feel-excited-about">I feel excited about</a></p></li></ul><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">5 Minute Timers</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think there are two main insights here:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Generate <em>then </em>filter ideas</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’m a massive perfectionist, and I find it easy to slip into the failure mode of generating the <em>perfect </em>idea. This is incredibly unhelpful, because this is paralysing in practice, and means I struggle to come up with anything. Any weak and half-formed ideas are discarded before they can be fleshed out into something worthwhile</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is an example of a general failure mode - trying to both generate and filter at the same time. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I find that these involve very different parts of my mind - generating ideas should feel free-flowing and diffuse, while filtering should feel constrained, directed and focused. And these different mindsets can’t be activated at once, so in practice I’m either neglecting one or rapidly switching between them</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This especially applies when it comes to any decision that feels scary or overwhelming - eg thinking about life decisions</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And this is super, super bad, because often the scariest thing is something unknown and fuzzy! By making the unknown feel clear and concrete, often it’ll feel a lot easier to pursue, so this leaves me stuck in a catch-22.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">For example, I was recently considering the idea of taking a gap year, and feeling a bit overwhelmed by the idea. So I decided to sit down for an hour, and generate a list of 50 different things I could do in that year. This was a really useful exercise, and would’ve been completely impossible if I’d spent that hour overwhelmed by the thought of actually <em>doing </em>any of them</p></li></ul></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Hard does not mean impossible</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A common failure mode is to feel <em>stuck </em>and give up. This is completely understandable! Feeling stuck is unpleasant and hard, and pushing through it takes <a href="https://neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">willpower</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But, in practice, while it may <em>feel </em>like being stuck means something is impossible, all it really means is that something is hard. This is important, because the solution to an impossible task should be to give up, while the solution to a hard task is often to just keep trying! This is a super common and subtle error, and it’s important to notice it in the moment</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I’ve found that overcoming this gets a lot easier with practice - it’s difficult to make yourself continue on a task that feels impossible and fruitless, even if you know it’s all in your head. Only after having some genuine successes can you begin to change how you feel about this.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">More generally, I find that overcoming this is a <em>key </em>subskill to becoming a <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/become-a-person-who-actually-does-things">person who Actually Does Things</a>, and to do anything particularly interesting or unusual. If it’s something that most people don’t or can’t do, then there will normally be some kind of mental barrier in the way. And while it’s valuable to know your limits, you should try to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/26-accurate-self-image">know your <em>true </em>limits</a>, not the cached thoughts of what you think your limits are.</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Of course, as with any insights that take willpower to apply, the solution is not to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-6-stop-pressing-the-try-harder-button">try harder</a>, it’s to <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">systematise them</a>! And my main tool here is to notice every time I want to be creative, set a 5 minute timer, get a blank document up or a piece of paper and generate solutions until the timer goes off.  </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is one of my favourite life hacks, for both sounding so ridiculously simple that there’s no way it actually works, and being incredibly useful in practice. This lets me implement both insights in a super low-willpower way! I spend the full 5 minutes generating and, because I’m under a fairly sharp time limit, it’s easy to remain focused. This means my mind rarely wanders, and I can maintain the mental distinction between generating and filtering, there isn’t enough <em>time </em>to get distracted like that! And it forces me to continue past getting stuck, because it’s only for 5 minutes! If I really need to, I can just sit there for 5 minutes staring at a blank piece of paper. But, in practice, I always come up with something.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Further, this is something you want to be systematised - it should be a <em>reflex</em>. I try to always have a physical timer within arms reach (I recommend <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?k=time%20timer&amp;ref=nb_sb_noss_2">this style</a> for great visuals) to make it as easy to do as possible (I also like the ability to say “Alexa, 5 minute timer”). And I’ve cultivated the habit of noticing any time I feel stuck, or out of ideas, or when I’m doing anything remotely <em>important</em>, and starting a 5 minute brainstorm. The fact that it’s 5 minutes, specifically, is pretty arbitrary, 4 or 6 minutes would work equally well. The point is to have a single default time, to minimise the activation energy of setting one. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>Even though </em>I’m fully convinced that 5 minute timers are awesome, an embarrassing amount of the time I still notice myself complaining about or dwelling on a problem without having spent at least 5 minutes trying to solve it! And I also notice this a lot in other people, to the point where one of my favourite questions to ask people is “have you spent at least 5 minutes thinking about this problem?”. 5 minutes is such a <em>short </em>amount of time, that I don’t think your answer to that question should ever be no. I think a great social norm, if you ever notice this failure mode in yourself or somebody else, is to set a 5 minute timer and have <em>both </em>of you think about the problem. (Anyone reading this has an open invitation to ask me this question if you ever think I’m not trying hard enough!)</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Frankly, I find it somewhat depressing that anything as simple as this is so useful. And I think it’s reasonable at this point in the article to feel skeptical. So, if you do, I propose a test: Set a 5 minute timer, and make a list of problems in your life - things that annoy you, things you want to work on, things that could be better. And then, go through that list, and cross off any you’re confident you’ve spent at least 5 minutes of focused time trying to solve. If you’re anything like me, you’ll have an embarrassingly long list left over. I’d be pretty curious about what happens if you try doing a 5 minute brainstorm for anything left.</p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Alternate sources</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Another great source of creativity is using other people! As <a href="http://mindingourway.com/obvious-advice/">Nate Soares notes</a>, often the advice that feels obvious to <em>me </em>doesn’t feel obvious to somebody else, and vice versa. We all have our standard toolkits, and ways of seeing the world. And these vary a lot between people! Asking people for advice or suggestions is almost universally useful when you want to expand your horizons of possible ideas. I’ve lost count of the number of times someone has given me a suggestion <em>they </em>thought was obvious that I’d never have come up with, but seemed instantly insightful when I heard it. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You can also use 5 minute timers in groups! Whenever I’m part of a group discussion, I think it’s extremely useful at the start to set a 5 minute timer, and have everyone generate ideas on their own, and then share. It’s super easy to get anchored on other people’s thoughts, and this ensures we can start out with a wide range of </p><p class="sqsrte-large" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Conclusion</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I think being creative is a <em>really </em>useful skill. And that if you aren’t setting 5 minute timers for yourself, you’re missing out on some incredibly low-hanging fruit. Cultivating this habit has significantly increased my ability to be creative, and come up with ideas I missed on the first pass. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">More generally, it’s difficult to <em>notice </em>in the moment to start a 5 minute timer. I think it can be useful to practice and explicitly develop the habit! I find it pretty consistently useful to try it on open-ended, introspective prompts (in, eg a weekly review). So, if this article has resonated with you, here are some examples I’ve found useful. I recommend picking a prompt that seems fun to you, and spending the next 5 minutes thinking about it! After all, <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-24-on-procrastination-the-art-of-shaping-your-future-actions">the best time to start a new habit is right now</a>. </p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I procrastinating about?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I stressing unnecessarily about?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s a mistake I’m currently making?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s something <em>really awesome </em>I could do today?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What obvious ideas am I currently missing?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s something nice I could do for somebody else?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What are the coolest things I’ve learned recently?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What’s my biggest bottleneck?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">What am I currently grateful for?</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Finally, if you’ve gotten through this entire article, and it doesn’t feel relevant to you. That you can’t come up with areas of your life where you’d like to be more creative. Then, well, that in itself feels like a lack of creativity. I’d be pretty curious to see what happens if you set a 5 minute timer, and try to generate places you <em>could </em>use these ideas.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">
  
    <span class="author-avatar content-fill" data-tweaks="tweak-show-blog-item-author-profile">
      <img class="author-avatar-image" data-controller="AuthorProfileImageLoader" data-src="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-image="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-load="false" alt="" />
    </span>
  
  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>
</a>



          </div>
        
      </div>

  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Interlude 2: Podcast episode on Effective Altruism </h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Jan 15" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Jan 15</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-60016820e5219e699321c03b"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-50d9610be0d6e2e1257c"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://art19.com/shows/not-overthinking/episodes/e8b83811-d327-4c7a-82fe-11487fd3df49">I was recently a guest on the Not Overthinking podcast</a>, run by <a href="https://aliabdaal.com/">Ali</a> &amp; <a href="https://taimur.me/">Taimur Abdaal</a>. I gave an introduction to the ideas on Effective Altruism (previously mentioned in ‘<a href="https://neelnanda.io/blog/8-altruism">What Altruism Means to Me</a>’). I’m very excited about this episode, EA ideas are a pretty big part of my life, and I like how it came out! </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Effective Altruism is all about figuring out how to improve the world as effectively as possible, and then actually doing it. To me, this feels like the natural application to altruism of rationality, life-optimisation, agency and all the other stuff I already talk about on this blog, and I tried to flesh out that link. If you enjoy my writing, I expect you’d also enjoy listening to this!</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Key points covered:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The key ideas of Effective Altruism, why it’s essential to prioritise effectiveness when doing good, and tools for thinking about impact</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You don’t have to be a saint to do good:<strong> </strong>How to <em>sustainably </em>prioritise doing good. Especially if, like me, you care much more about doing good on an intellectual level than an emotional level</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">General career advice, why altruism should be a major factor in career plans, and what to do about this</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Random tangents, like how I’ve optimised my ability to have close friendships and emotional bonds, and how to actually come up with life goals in the first place</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Find <a href="https://art19.com/shows/not-overthinking/episodes/e8b83811-d327-4c7a-82fe-11487fd3df49">here</a>, or on your favourite podcast player (Podcast is Not Overthinking, episode is How can we optimise for a meaningful life?)</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>(If you’ve just come to this blog via this episode, welcome, and apologies for a post that’s clearly not interesting to you! I have a bunch of other essays that I expect to be much more novel. Subscribe </em><a href="http://eepurl.com/g7ZUxH"><em>here</em></a><em> for new posts, and look at </em><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/top-posts"><em>top posts</em></a><em> for suggestions on where to start)</em></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">
  
    <span class="author-avatar content-fill" data-tweaks="tweak-show-blog-item-author-profile">
      <img class="author-avatar-image" data-controller="AuthorProfileImageLoader" data-src="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-image="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-load="false" alt="" />
    </span>
  
  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>
</a>



          </div>

          firstSection.style.paddingTop = headerHeight + 'px';

        if (sectionBackground && isLayoutEngineSection) {
          if (isFirstSectionInset) {

  data-section-theme="light"

    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
  &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
  &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
  &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
  &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
  &quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,
  &quot;contentWidth&quot;: &quot;content-width--wide&quot;,
  &quot;customContentWidth&quot;: 50,
  &quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;light&quot;,

  data-animation="none"

  <div class="section-background">

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Interlude 2: Podcast episode on Effective Altruism </h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Jan 15" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Jan 15</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" id="item-60016820e5219e699321c03b"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-50d9610be0d6e2e1257c"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://art19.com/shows/not-overthinking/episodes/e8b83811-d327-4c7a-82fe-11487fd3df49">I was recently a guest on the Not Overthinking podcast</a>, run by <a href="https://aliabdaal.com/">Ali</a> &amp; <a href="https://taimur.me/">Taimur Abdaal</a>. I gave an introduction to the ideas on Effective Altruism (previously mentioned in ‘<a href="https://neelnanda.io/blog/8-altruism">What Altruism Means to Me</a>’). I’m very excited about this episode, EA ideas are a pretty big part of my life, and I like how it came out! </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Effective Altruism is all about figuring out how to improve the world as effectively as possible, and then actually doing it. To me, this feels like the natural application to altruism of rationality, life-optimisation, agency and all the other stuff I already talk about on this blog, and I tried to flesh out that link. If you enjoy my writing, I expect you’d also enjoy listening to this!</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Key points covered:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The key ideas of Effective Altruism, why it’s essential to prioritise effectiveness when doing good, and tools for thinking about impact</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You don’t have to be a saint to do good:<strong> </strong>How to <em>sustainably </em>prioritise doing good. Especially if, like me, you care much more about doing good on an intellectual level than an emotional level</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">General career advice, why altruism should be a major factor in career plans, and what to do about this</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Random tangents, like how I’ve optimised my ability to have close friendships and emotional bonds, and how to actually come up with life goals in the first place</p></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Find <a href="https://art19.com/shows/not-overthinking/episodes/e8b83811-d327-4c7a-82fe-11487fd3df49">here</a>, or on your favourite podcast player (Podcast is Not Overthinking, episode is How can we optimise for a meaningful life?)</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>(If you’ve just come to this blog via this episode, welcome, and apologies for a post that’s clearly not interesting to you! I have a bunch of other essays that I expect to be much more novel. Subscribe </em><a href="http://eepurl.com/g7ZUxH"><em>here</em></a><em> for new posts, and look at </em><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/top-posts"><em>top posts</em></a><em> for suggestions on where to start)</em></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">
  
    <span class="author-avatar content-fill" data-tweaks="tweak-show-blog-item-author-profile">
      <img class="author-avatar-image" data-controller="AuthorProfileImageLoader" data-src="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-image="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/images/5ed927252ed2b33a91fbb122" data-load="false" alt="" />
    </span>
  
  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>
</a>



          </div>
        
      </div>

            </div>

      </section>
    </div>

      </span>
    </a>
  
  
    <a href="/blog/rationality-retrospective" class="item-pagination-link item-pagination-link--next">
      <div class="pagination-title-wrapper">
        
        <div class="visually-hidden">Next</div>
        <div class="item-pagination-prev-next">Next</div>
        
        <h2 class="item-pagination-title">Interlude: Retrospective on Teaching Rationality Workshops</h2>
      </div>
      <div class="item-pagination-icon icon icon--stroke">
        <svg class="caret-right-icon--small" viewBox="0 0 9 16">
          <polyline fill="none" stroke-miterlimit="10" points="1.6,1.2 6.5,7.9 1.6,14.7"/>
        </svg>
      </div>
    </a>
  
</section>

          
          
        
      </main>
      <script type="text/javascript">
        const firstSection = document.querySelector('.page-section');
        const header = document.querySelector('.header');
        const mobileOverlayNav = document.querySelector('.header-menu');
        const sectionBackground = firstSection ? firstSection.querySelector('.section-background') : null;
        const headerHeight = header ? header.getBoundingClientRect().height : 0;
        const firstSectionHasBackground = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('has-background') >= 0 : false;
        const isFirstSectionInset = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('background-width--inset') >= 0 : false;
        const isLayoutEngineSection = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('layout-engine-section') >= 0 : false;

        if (firstSection) {
          firstSection.style.paddingTop = headerHeight + 'px';
        }
        if (sectionBackground && isLayoutEngineSection) {
          if (isFirstSectionInset) {
            sectionBackground.style.top = headerHeight + 'px';
          } else {
            sectionBackground.style.top = '';
          }
        }
        //# sourceURL=headerPositioning.js
      </script>

          <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">
  
    <section
  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"
  class='page-section
    
      content-collection
      full-bleed-section
      collection-type-blog-basic-grid
    
    background-width--full-bleed
    
      section-height--medium
    
    
      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
  &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
  &quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
  &quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
  &quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
  &quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,
  &quot;contentWidth&quot;: &quot;content-width--wide&quot;,
  &quot;customContentWidth&quot;: 50,
  &quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;light&quot;,
  &quot;sectionAnimation&quot;: &quot;none&quot;,
  &quot;backgroundMode&quot;: &quot;image&quot;
}"
  data-animation="none"
   
  
    
  
>
  <div class="section-background">
  
    
  
  </div>
  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-basic-grid-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">Mini Blog Post 8: What altruism means to me</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Jun 17" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Jun 17</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233" class="blog-author-name">Neel Nanda</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" data-updated-on="1592926442547" id="item-5ee9bad6c76c2a7ba4bf6279"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-372caeaab843a16ed0cf"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">This is a pretty different post from the ones so far. This post is an attempt to outline my personal moral views, where they come from, and how this affects my life. Morality is super, super complicated and nuanced, and I cannot possibly cover all of my views in a short blog post. So I’m focusing more on covering the broad strokes of my views, and the parts that feel most important to me, and skipping over a lot of complex edge cases (damn population ethics). I also think morality is <em>highly </em>subjective, and many of you will disagree with these, but I hope it’s of some interest and resonates with some of you!</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">One of the core tenets of my view is that human life has intrinsic value. Every life represents a person, someone with a story, hopes, dreams, fears. People who they care about, and who care about them. Decades of history, and memories, leading up to where they are today, and a long potential future stretching out ahead of them. And I think every life is beautiful, and precious, and to be cherished. And, importantly, what matters is that <em>they </em>exist. I think it is important that people exist, as a fact about the world. Often I see people justifying caring as “because it makes me feel good” or “because I’ll feel guilty if I don’t”, and this is <em>not </em>what I am saying here. I care about human happiness and welfare as an intrinsic fact about the world, not as a fact that exists within my mind. Even if I will never meet them, or interact with them at all, I want these people to exist and flourish.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And this is <em>important </em>- I will preserve a human life over many other things. I care about people’s suffering, and pleasure, and a whole host of other things. And when suffering continues for a long period of time, like severe depression, I think it can be comparable to lives in importance. But given the chance to save a life, at the cost of causing someone else some <em>temporary </em>pain and unhappiness, I would consider this an excellent trade. Mental states are important, but <em>far </em>less important than saving a life. And, importantly, this same logic should apply if the temporary unhappiness is caused to me. If there is a way that I can help somebody else, at some cost to myself, then it is morally correct to do so.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">So far, I don’t think any of this is controversial. But the conventional notion of altruism is one that I strongly disagree with. There is a big focus on being caring, helping others and doing what <em>feels </em>like the right thing. And I am a big fan of the impulse to care that this represents - I think this is the source of a lot of what I value about people. But often the impulse to care doesn’t result in the action that truly helps the most people. It’s much more <em>satisfying </em>to help those dear to me, or even the people I see in need in my country, and my community. But it’s a sad fact about the world that these impulses do <em>not </em>always lead to the best action. For example, when a an earthquake happens in a poor country, I feel a strong draw to donate money to help people. It’s something big, and attention grabbing, and there are clearly people suffering and in need. Yet, most money spent on disaster relief doesn’t go to good use, and far more lives could be saved by spending that same money on better preparation and infrastructure. So, I have a choice between two worlds: helping a few people and feeling great about myself, or helping many more people but without feeling that same warm feelings. Essentially, I’m trading a <em>large </em>quantity of other people’s welfare to improve my own mental state. I think this is a difficult decision, but not one where there’s really any doubt about the right choice. True altruism is not about doing the right thing because it feels good. It’s about realising that the right thing is <em>not </em>what feels best, and doing it anyway.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The overall point I’m trying to convey, is that morality is not about following your intuitions, it’s about doing <strong>the action that will most improve the world</strong>. And this is important, because our intuitions are a <em>bad </em>guide to morality. Because morality is about making the <em>world </em>a better place, while our intuitions come from within our own minds. Our intuitions are tools we evolved while living in tribes of hundreds of people, and do not extend well to the complex modern world. A human life is worth the same, no matter where you are in the world, yet people who are close and familiar <em>feel </em>much more compelling. Saving a thousand lives feels about as great as saving three thousand, because my mind never evolved a good intuition for large numbers. But this is a problem with my mind, not with the world - each of those extra two thousand lives is a person, and their life is precious to <em>them</em>. And it is unpleasant and demotivating to actively ignore these intuitions. But by following my intuitions, I’m putting value on the feeling in my head, which is <em>nothing </em>on the scales of moral worth compared to a human life.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And we know that intuitions are a bad guide, in other areas of our life. If I’m investing money, I <em>know </em>it’s dumb to just buy the stocks I have a good feeling about - this is a difficult problem that requires careful thought. If I’m arguing with a friend, and I <em>feel </em>convinced that I’m right, I should ignore this and hear them out. Because their friendship is important to me, and I care about them. Because these are difficult and important problems, and what matters is finding <em>truth </em>and the right answer, and our intuitions are an imperfect guide to this. Doing the right thing is, quite literally, a matter of life and death. And it’s easy to ignore this, because the pain and suffering is somebody <em>else</em>’s problem. But this is a problem with my mind, not with the world. Exactly how to do the right thing is a complex and difficult question, which I am very far from understanding, but it is undoubtedly one that matters. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It’s easy to see questions of morality as something ungrounded and philosophical, or as some external imposition. Something to think about on occasion, and feel guilty about, but ignore in day-to-day life. And this is extremely easy to do. We live in a culture where it’s completely fine to focus on your happiness, rather than the countless strangers who are suffering. There won’t be any consequences to you of not thinking about this question. But this is a question that genuinely matters to me, and I think it has broad implications as to how I live my life. I’m healthy, from a rich country, with good healthcare and infrastructure. I’m fortunate enough to be studying at one of the most elite institutions in the world, with a family able to support me. I have a position of privilege, as do most of the people reading this. I have a lot of resources, and will have a lot more over the rest of my life. I have a lot of potential to improve the world, if I choose to do so. And it would be easy to just ignore all of this, and leave this all as a latent guilt at the back of my mind. I don’t think I have an obligation to do this, and there’s nobody forcing me to. But altruism is about figuring out the right thing to do, realising you don’t <em>need </em>to do it, and doing it anyway.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">At this point, it’s natural to start thinking about demandingness. It’s natural to convert this logic into a guilt complex, a feeling of obligation to always do the right thing. And many reject this logic here: it’s exhausting and unsustainable to <em>always </em>care about doing good. And I think this is a really important point! It’s easy to frame altruism as a need to sacrifice, a need to self-flagellate, and I think this is the same error as the caring altruist who never does a cost-benefit calculation. Self-sacrifice is a fact about my mind, not the world, and morality is about the world. There is no <em>inherent</em> need for self-sacrifice and guilt, it is <em>only </em>useful if these feelings lead to a better world.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And a convenient fact about the world is that I will often do more good by doing things I enjoy, rather than things that I hate. Most of the value I can add is over the course of my career, and people are <em>far </em>more productive when they feel engaged and fulfilled by their work. And altruism is <a href="https://80000hours.org/career-guide/job-satisfaction/#2-work-that-helps-others">something that people find genuinely fulfilling</a>, and can be a source of a lot of happiness. I think some people have a feeling that it’s not <em>true </em>altruism if there’s no element of personal sacrifice, but I think this is wholeheartedly all amazing! If you can do good, and feel awesome doing it, that it strictly better than doing good and it feeling like a harsh sacrifice. Because your feelings are a fact about your mind, not about the world. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Further, guilt and obligation are <a href="http://mindingourway.com/guilt/">poor motivators in the longterm</a>. Doing good is a marathon, not a sprint. I will do <em>far </em>more for the world if I spend my whole life trying, rather than burning out in my youth. You get a lot more work done by taking breaks, and time to maintain your mental health, rather than pushing yourself until you break. So I think it’s completely fine to not sweat the small things, to indulge in luxuries and frivolities without a shred of guilt. What matters is ensuring that the <em>big </em>choices are made well. What career you pursue, which causes you value, the places you donate to and how much you donate.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I strongly identify as part of the <a href="https://www.ted.com/talks/will_macaskill_what_are_the_most_important_moral_problems_of_our_time?language=en">Effective Altruism</a> movement, though this reasoning is my own path there, and many people in the movement will have different views on these questions. I don’t agree with the movement on everything, and there are almost certainly important questions we are both wrong about. But it’s the one movement I’ve found that seems to really <em>get </em>that doing good is about what happens in the world, not what happens in your head. That you should be unbiased and search for the cause area that does the most good. That you should use the evidence-backed tools that we know work, realise when the evidence shows your treasured beliefs are false, and let go of them. That doing good is a difficult question, but one that is crucial to answer as well as we possibly can. </p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And if the ideas in this post resonated with you, you would be extremely welcome to join us. The first step to doing the most good is prioritising and figuring out <em>how</em>. And though the thoughts of EA are far from perfect or complete, I’ve found them a highly valuable framework. If you’re a student, I think most of the value you can add to the world will come from what you do with your life post-graduation, and predominantly from your career, and <a href="https://80000hours.org/key-ideas/">80000 Hours</a> have a lot of useful thoughts on this. <a href="http://givewell.org/">GiveWell</a> do excellent research into some of the world’s best charities. If you’re in Cambridge, you’d be very welcome at events run by EA Cambridge.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">These are difficult and complex questions, but I think are important to get right. And though I’ve gone far beyond the time I’d set for writing this post, I have many more thoughts than I could fit into here. So if you’re interested in learning more about this, and would find it helpful to talk to me more about it, you are very welcome to book a time in <a href="http://calendly.com/neelnanda1011/ea-chat-with-neel">here</a>.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

        

        
        
          <div class="blog-item-author-profile-wrapper" data-content-field="author">
            <a href="/?author=5ed927247689ec0247c03233">

  <span class="author-name">Neel Nanda</span>

id="linkedin-unauth-icon" viewBox="0 0 64 64"><path d="M20.4,44h5.4V26.6h-5.4V44z M23.1,18c-1.7,0-3.1,1.4-3.1,3.1c0,1.7,1.4,3.1,3.1,3.1 c1.7,0,3.1-1.4,3.1-3.1C26.2,19.4,24.8,18,23.1,18z M46,44h-5.4v-8.4c0-2,0-4.6-2.8-4.6c-2.8,0-3.2,2.2-3.2,4.5V44h-5.4V26.6 h5.2V29h0.1c0.7-1.4,2.5-2.8,5.1-2.8c5.5,0,6.5,3.6,6.5,8.3V44z"/></symbol></svg>

</html>. looking for source of err msg

Logging new message at Sat May  1 17:08:35 2021
initing bs4 with <!doctype html>
<html xmlns:og="http://opengraphprotocol.org/schema/" xmlns:fb="http://www.facebook.com/2008/fbml" lang="en-US"  >
  <head>

  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme=""
  class='page-section
    
      layout-engine-section

  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
  &quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
  &quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,

  <div
    class="content-wrapper"
    style='
      
        
      
    '
  >
    <div
      class="content"
      
    >
      
      
      
      
      
      <div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-type="page-section" id="page-section-5f798d9e82e94e42ed860394"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-0ea4fb98431f0a85a2fe"><div class="sqs-block-content"><h2 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Top Posts</h2><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I have a lot of posts, so people often ask me where to start! This is my attempt to give a rough categorisation of the things I often write and think about, and my favourite posts in each category. This is in no particular order, and I recommend reading whatever stands out as sounding fun! If you just want a single starting point, the post I’m proudest of writing is <a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/8-altruism">my post on altruism</a></p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Altruism</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/8-altruism">What altruism means to me</a> - on my moral beliefs and how they’ve led me to the Effective Altruism movement</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Motivation</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/become-a-person-who-actually-does-things">Become a person who Actually Does Things</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-11-live-a-life-you-feel-excited-about">Live a life you feel excited about</a> - how to shape your life to be full of intrinsic motivation</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/35-standards">Your standards are too high</a> - on guilt, obligation and setting realistic standards for yourself</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Productivity</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-19-on-systems-living-a-life-of-zero-willpower">On systems</a> - building routines and systems into your life, so that you do the right thing <em>by default </em>rather than by “trying harder”</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Procrastination</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-24-on-procrastination-the-art-of-shaping-your-future-actions">On procrastination</a> - my toolkit for overcoming procrastination, and taking actions that achieve my values</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Education</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-18-how-to-teach-things-well">How to teach things well</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/34-learning">Learning how to learn</a> - my personal learning style, and my advice for how to get better at learning</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Social skills</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-5-how-to-learn-from-conversations">How to learn from conversations</a></p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-23-taking-social-initiative">Taking social initiative</a></p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Life-optimisation</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-22-the-8020-rule">The world is full of wasted motion</a> - an argument that the world is full of low-hanging fruit, incentives are poorly aligned, and there <em>should </em>be major returns to optimisation</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/33-upside-risk">Seek upside risk</a> - fill your life with things that have the potential to go <em>incredibly </em>well</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/39-reflection">On reflection</a> - make regular time to reflect on your life and notice what you could be doing differently. Make improving things the <em>default</em>.</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Pitfalls of optimisation</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/mini-blog-post-9-what-it-means-to-optimise">What it means to optimise</a> - why I try to optimise my life for my goals, and common mistakes of optimisation</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/38-slack">On Slack - Having room to be excited</a> - the importance of leaving yourself spare capacity in your life, rather than trying to push everything to its limits</p></li></ul></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Creativity</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/27-retrospective">On blog posts</a> - Why you should start a daily writing project</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://www.neelnanda.io/blog/post-28-on-creativity-the-joys-of-5-minute-timers">On creativity</a> - how 5 minute timers are an exceptionally powerful tool for becoming more creative</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And if you’ve enjoyed my writing, you can subscribe to hear about new posts <a href="http://eepurl.com/g7ZUxH">here</a>! And I’d love to hear any feedback to help me become a better writer <a href="https://forms.gle/g7EAPrymDiBLgnLm7">here</a></p></div></div></div></div></div>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

      <script type="text/javascript">
        const firstSection = document.querySelector('.page-section');
        const header = document.querySelector('.header');
        const mobileOverlayNav = document.querySelector('.header-menu');
        const sectionBackground = firstSection ? firstSection.querySelector('.section-background') : null;
        const headerHeight = header ? header.getBoundingClientRect().height : 0;
        const firstSectionHasBackground = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('has-background') >= 0 : false;
        const isFirstSectionInset = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('background-width--inset') >= 0 : false;
        const isLayoutEngineSection = firstSection ? firstSection.className.indexOf('layout-engine-section') >= 0 : false;

        if (firstSection) {
          firstSection.style.paddingTop = headerHeight + 'px';
        }
        if (sectionBackground && isLayoutEngineSection) {
          if (isFirstSectionInset) {
            sectionBackground.style.top = headerHeight + 'px';
          } else {
            sectionBackground.style.top = '';
          }
        }
        //# sourceURL=headerPositioning.js
      </script>

      <main id="page" class="container" role="main">
        
          <article class="sections" data-page-sections="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a09" id="sections">
  
    <section
  data-test="page-section"
  
  data-section-theme="light"
  class='page-section
    
      content-collection
      full-bleed-section
      collection-type-blog-basic-grid
    
    background-width--full-bleed
    
      section-height--medium
    
    
      content-width--wide
    
    horizontal-alignment--center
    vertical-alignment--middle
    
    
    light'
  
  data-section-id="5ed9281a6f8e241f17631a0b"
  
  data-controller="SectionWrapperController, MagicPaddingController"
  data-current-styles="{
&quot;imageOverlayOpacity&quot;: 0.15,
&quot;backgroundWidth&quot;: &quot;background-width--full-bleed&quot;,
&quot;sectionHeight&quot;: &quot;section-height--medium&quot;,
&quot;customSectionHeight&quot;: 10,
&quot;horizontalAlignment&quot;: &quot;horizontal-alignment--center&quot;,
&quot;verticalAlignment&quot;: &quot;vertical-alignment--middle&quot;,
&quot;contentWidth&quot;: &quot;content-width--wide&quot;,
&quot;customContentWidth&quot;: 50,
&quot;sectionTheme&quot;: &quot;light&quot;,
&quot;sectionAnimation&quot;: &quot;none&quot;,
